Augmentations give the player new avenues into approaching objectives which allows the game to feel more open ended and replayable.BE WARNED, not all augmentations can be purchased in one playthrough so choose wisely depending on your playstyle.5th time playing it myself (1st time on PC), and I was still discovering new and rewarding approaches to tackle my objectives. The dialogue system, which is very similar to Mass Effect, works extremely well in giving the player more choice and is intricately designed, much like the new hacking system. As far as the story goes, it absolutely works with the themes of the game. Conspiracies, secret organisations and of course...the Illuminati. And not to mention, the writing in the game is impeccable. One of the best scripts I've seen in a video game.The "Directors Cut" tag has added quite a few benefits over the original, the most noticeable being the New Game+ mode which was widely requested by fans for a long time. It's here and it absolutely works. Being able to continue on from where the game ended and keeping all augmentations just makes the game more enjoyable and also a little bit easier, allowing the "Give me Deus Ex" difficulty to be quite manageable, as it is very tough (1 or 2 hits and its "See ya later, Frank"). Only weapons and other inventory items will have been discarded if New Game+ is activated, which is not a very big hassle as it would have made the game way too easy, and that is not at all good for a game like this. The new "Directors Cut" also adds developer commentary which is quite insightful as it delves deeper into how different aspects of the game were considered and made.In conclusion, Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Directors Cut is one of last generation’s best games, in MY OPINION. The rewarding gameplay, multiple approaches to objectives, and just the sheer amount of replayability along with the engaging and well written 20+ hour storyline makes for an extremely enjoyable and immersive experience, especially for fans of the franchise, like myself. The only downsides, which I haven't yet mentioned have to be that the game only rewards one approach of gameplay, stealth and non-lethal, which is actually fine because ultimately this is how Deus Ex should be played, and it’s the way I played it. The other disappointment is in the boss fights. Although the "Directors Cut" added more flexibility to these encounters, they still lacked in the multiple approach department, especially taking these bosses down non-lethally, which isn't very much like Deus Ex. Lastly, the inclusion of the "Missing Link" DLC, adds to the games total play time, but nothing more as it is quite a disappointment. The "Missing Link" should not have been embedded into the main game, as it seems rather forced due to the tedious objectives that need to be completed in a constricted hub, which ultimately results in rather stale and boring gameplay. All in all, I wish I could go over everything, but this was a short review. Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Directors Cut is one hell of a game and can easily be respected as one of the series' best. Hardcore fan or newcomer, this game should be played by anyone who enjoys lasting and rewarding RPG's. Having played the PC and console version, the PC version is far superior.9.3/10Note: I managed to do everything in the game, including most achievements and the DLC, in around 17 hours (speedrun, kinda). If it is your FIRST time playing the game, expect to put in at least 30-35 hours to finish the story and do some of the side quests. I just memorised MOST of the games layout and approaches, and also knew where the main interest locations were.

content:
10, 2016
												Short Version:Everything is orange. Everything can kill you quickly with well-placed headshots, so get in cover. The cover system is clunky. The lethal guns are fun. Not enough explosions or destruction for me. The story is meh and hte game feels a little short... But still nice.7/10 would reccomend to buy on sale, but is still great either way.Long version:Everything is clunky, but ok in it's own odd way, and every gun in the game is useful (at least the lethal ones, I didn't bother with silly concepts like "restraint" or "stealth and subtlty" or "mercy" or "doing the right thing." :P) I blasted my way through the game and had fun getting yelled at by every character who had a problem with it (I only wish you could flip them off more often.)I found myself dying and reloading saves often, and my advice is to use the weapons you have now, and not bother with sparing ammunition. You'll almost always have the resources to spare, especially near the end of the game where you're an expert at placing one-hit-kill headshots on your enemies like no tomorrow. So seriously! Hurl that grenade, don't stash it! You'll miss out on all the fun if you're just using the pistol all the time or saving your superpower energy!I kind of wish the game's story was a little clearer. I still don't know what Adam's initial mission was- something about figuring out who's behind a terrorist attack at the Sans Serif Font Building or something. The relationship between Adam and the girlfriend was shoehorned into the plot, and Adam Jensen's voice actor doesn't emote half the time, and needs a throat lozenge (seriously, it's really bad. I reflexively cringe half the time that he talks.)All three endings to the game (without spoiling anything) are just essentially slideshows, like Fallout.Unsorted thoughts on the game:-Alcohol blurrs the screen really badly, and it's unreasonable. It's also hard to use items in your inventory. You would think that sorting your inventory by clicking and dragging would be easy, but somehow it's not. Using items that aren't on your hotbar requres the use of a dropdown menu, like you're in windows Explorer. Even dropping items.-Your inventory gets pretty small, even when you can upgrade it. It would be kind of fun to not have to worry about inventory space, like in Half Life, but meh.-Everything is orange. I suggest downloading a mod to remove the silly orange filter, because it gets kind of annoying, especially when you get to the China area.The city hubs are a little... Dull. Not a lot of things going on, just lots of people standing around in the street. There are two city hubs: Detroit, and Generic China Future City with bad stereotypical accents. I hate "China City Who's Name I've Already Forgotten." It's layout is like a maze, and you get lost easily, even with a map and a compass. A simple task of getting from objective to objective turns into a game of wandering until you find the right path.Mine templates are useless. It's hard to gauge how far a thrown weapon will go, and sometimes you'll have to throw a second grenade because you missed. Stores don't sell enough ammo. There's not enough superpowers, but the ones you have are awesome.The cover system is really poorly implemented, and sometimes it doesn't even work right in firefights- jerking your gun around suddenly or in directions that you didn't expect.Even with full armor upgrades, a pointblank shotgun blast will still almost always kill you in a single hit. This makes the game unforgivingly hard.One last note: I -HATE- the sprint function. You run for literally three seconds at maybe 10% faster speed, then have to wait three seconds to recharge it. Sure, you can spend valuable exp on expanding that sprint by two increments of 2.5 seconds each, but it doesn't do much of anything.All in all, a flawed gem.

content:
14, 2016
												This may very well be one of the longest reviews I will ever write...First off, I'll admit it. When I first played Deus Ex: Human Revolution, I didn't like it at all. I found the game to be boring and difficult. It may also have something to do with the fact that I first played this on the Playstation 3, but I digress. The fact is, this game is probably unlike any other game I've ever played in my life.You play as Adam Jensen, an ex-cop now working for Sarif Industries, a massive company that is pretty much the poster-boy for cyberpunk mega-conglomerates. When the company is about to move to a new location, it gets hit by a terrorist attack, leaving Jensen near-death while he watches his lover, Megan Reed, get killed. In typical Robocop fashion, he is rebuilt using  AUGMENTATIONS™  . Six months later, he is back at the company, and is now on a quest to discover the truth of what really happened that fateful night.As far as presentation goes, I've heard a lot of people give this game a hard time for having a consistently yellow/orange aesthetic to it. Personally, I didn't mind this that much, and thought the game looked fine. Actually, I'd say that in a lot of areas, the game looks fantastic, especially on some of the later levels. (I personally thought that the penthouse level was absolutely gorgeous) There's so many fine details in every nook and cranny in this game, that it really makes the game look and feel like it's own universe. Of course, looking at the Final Fantasy games, this is to be expected from Square Enix. If I really have any complaints, I thought that the characters sometimes felt a bit robotic, and the lip-syncing can kinda get screwy at times. However, this is a pretty small problem that can be overlooked.I say that because, for the most part, the voice actors really do a good job; putting a lot of effort forth for some pretty riveting dialogue at times. I personally thought that the voice actor of Jensen, Elias Toufexis, did an amazing job potraying his role. As a matter of fact, the sound design in most of the game is actually really good; the guns sound like they have a punch to them, and of course, a bunch of little details here and there that, again, make this game truly come to life. Now, when it comes to the music, it ranges from "pretty good" to "♥♥♥♥ing incredible". Some of the tracks on here are an audible feast. I just hope that Mankind Divided has just as good of a soundtrack, if not better.In typical Deus Ex fashion, you are given a wide array of choices and methods of getting past levels. You can go in guns blazing, sneak around Metal Gear style and take out enemies quickly and quietly, you can hack turrets, turn off security cameras, and you can even go through levels quietly without killing anybody, if you'd like. And that's not even all you can do. Throughout the game, you get Praxis points which you can use to level up your augmentations. You can spend these on new abilities, such as seeing through walls, being able to hack harder terminals, to fall any height without taking damage, lift heavy objects such as vending machines and dumpsters, and much more. Jensen controls pretty solidly, so you won't have too much trouble pulling off any play style you wish to go in with. Out of all of these, I'd say that Hacking is probably an essential skill to level up, as the game is extremely difficult without it. There's actually a hacking minigame this time around instead of waiting for the ICE Breaker bar to deplete. It's not incredibly hard, and it does add tension to the game at times, because the world around you doesn't freeze when you're in hacking, so keep an eye on your surroundings before you hack something.Personally, I don't think you need to play the first Deus Ex in order to appreciate this one, as it is a prequel to the first one. Even if you aren't familiar with the first game at all, I think this game is well-crafted enough for a large number of people to enjoy.If I have any other complaints, is that there are some sections of this game that do get extremely frustrating. This may have been a foul-up on my part, but still, some parts of this game had me FURIOUS. I personally think this is one of the best games of the 2010's. It's action-packed, it's smart, and it's a pretty lengthy game if you're into that sort of thing. I finally clocked in at about 16 hours when I did my first playthrough of this game. It's one hell of a ride.10 augmented, cyberpunk, haXX0r McLovin's out of 10.

content:
ber 8, 2016
												In retrospect the original DX is, without doubt, an unforgetable but flawed masterpiece which pushed the technology of the day to, and sometimes beyond, the limit. The Hell's Kitchen level is still a design classic, the overall story is still as strong as it ever was but graphics, AI, and shooter mechanic are showing their age. In comparison, HR has improved with age and now seems more topical than ever. HR is more cinematic and sure-footed than DX. The story is deep,  immaculately scripted and there is a sense that the characters are real people. There is also an overall artistic vision missing from the original DX. However, all is not perfect with HR; it was pushed out of the workshop with rough edges and annoying game balance problems. DX:HR Director's Cut includes all of the DLC and a gameplay rebalance. At the moment I am in the basement of the Picus building and playing a ghost/no-kill game on maximum difficulty. It's a worthy challenge. The annoyances involved with  ghosting through the original HR are gone. I had to kill Barret at Highland Park by turning the sentry guns against him, but he deserved it. Coming back to  HR is like meeting a trusted friend after many years; I see things I missed before and have a new appreciation of just how good this game is. Maybe it's a design masterpiece?---the final emergence of the video game as a fully formed story telling artform. It could be the video game equivalent of Casablanca or Citizen Kane. Maybe. Time will tell.

												I spent more than 50 hours playing this game on the PS3, now on the PC and I will keep playing it until Mankind Divided hits the market. People who complain about this game have clearly not taken the time to look at all its details. Human Revolution has a rich story and a very good gameplay. The characters are interesting (although they sometimes have pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ animations, but *shrugs*), the main character is awesome and has a very interesting character design, I LOVE his german voice. I think the english one sounds too... rough, emotionless and monotonous, if not even bored. I loved the level designs, loved the different locations... And, like I said, the story is... wow. It does not happen often, but I am able to play this game again and again without getting bored of the story. The conspiracies, the stuff you learn about transhumanism,... Seriously. People who think this game sucks, clearly have no time to explore the whole world of Deus Ex: Human Revolution. I have hacked nearly every computer in the game, read all E-Books and PDAs. Most people seem to forget that it is in fact a Roleplaying Game. Not a CoD like "let me shoot everything that comes in front of my gun". A RPG is about exploring the world. If you have no time for that, then you should probably have a look at other game genres :)

content:
ber 3, 2016
												The dev team thought of everything.Other reviews can praise this game's stealth, combat, upgrades, art, characters, and story, I just want to show my appreciation for the sheer amount of player choice in this game. Sometimes I was flabbergasted after a mission, going back through the level and realizing just how impressive its design was in terms of making sure that you can get through it ANY way you want to. Pacifict? Check. Terminator? Check. Hacker? Scavenger? Little-of-everything? All of the above. I loved it.And more than just the amount of choice was the implementation. I've said in other reviews that what I want in a game is one where the challenge comes from fighting the bad guys, not from fighting the controls. 99% of everything I tried in this game was a fair challenge. No shoddy, sloppy work. I push the button; thing happens the way it's supposed to. And there were plenty of times when I had a nutty idea and thought, 'Can I do that?' Yes I could. Punch civilians in the head! Throw turrets into the sea! Make modern art with piles of unconscious enemies! Steal EVERYTHING!My only real complaint was with the implanted DLC. While I did grow to enjoy it by the end, (especially Quinn), at times it felt uneccesary and shoehorned in, and there were parts when the writing was bizarrely sexist. Oh well. Once I got off the boat it was back to the main game and everything was fine again.Overall, DXHR is going in my favorites list. I look forward to New Game+. The D-Row Ballers won't know what hit 'em.P.S. Major congrats to Adam Jensen's voice actor. The Neo-esque gravelly growl could have easily been monotone and emotionless, but he managed to put a ton of subtle personality into the performance. Often through taking the lines as read, and knowing exactly which words to punch emphasis into. Kudos!

content:
ry 12
												It's been a good 13 years or so since first I played the (amazing) Deus Ex and attempted to go back to back with the Deus Ex sequel, Invisble War. Yeah, that didn't go so well. Deus Ex featured open ended, globe trotting goodness  while IW felt like a crappy console port. Thankfully the third game in the series, Human Revolution, has rediscovered the original's roots and paves it's own way into excellence. I'm not going to go into the story of DE: HR becuase frankly the story is lengthy, complicated and is ever changing depending on your decisions. But don't let that scare you off because it is absolutely engrossing. I'd refer to DE: HR more as a "First Person RPG". Gameplay is at it's best when you're sneaking around, diagnosing, and using your brain to find ways around situations. It's especially satisfying when you have robot or turret domination. Press the button to get them on your side and listen to chaos ensue. However, if you're looking to gun your way through this game I'd say you'll be disappointed. The shooting is extremely "eh" and even with your armor maxed, the enemies will be able to take more damage than you.  Also kind of on the eh side is everything really looks the same. You'll be inside most of the time crawling through corridors, sewers and air vents. WAY more to like though. The soundtrack is great and overall the voice acting is as well. There are so many solutions to the problems in this game, even if you're underpowered you'll get through it. The campaign is incredibly lengthy and there are tons of side missions for you to do. I wholeheartedly recommend DE: HR but I can see why this game wouldn't be for everyone.  As long as you aren't expecting a CoD one man army style of shooter it's hard to imagine you'd be disappointed. 9/10 from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 14, 2016
TL;DRHolds up marvelously for a (at the time of writing) 5 year old game, Deus Ex: Human Revolution (DXHR) is a game that strives to let each player enjoy the experience in his or her way.Meeghan!!!How do you revive a game series more than a decade old? DX:HR should be a shining example of such an accomplishment. It took a story-line with potential, mixed it with a bag full of modern tricks and we end up with a fun to play game and a solid adventure to boot. Perhaps the most exemplary of it's traits is that this is a game that offers a stealth option, and then actually rewards the player for playing stealthily. This is a true adventure-stealth game, as evidenced by the fact that one can go through the game without killing a single enemy (save for the bosses). BreakdownPros You Can't See Me: No need to go into every situation guns blazing. Play it Again: Even though the storyline is linear, there's no reason the gameplay is. The game is choc ful of shortcuts and hidden secrets that you'll definitely want to replay it again. Decisions decisions: How you play, what paths you choose, and choices you make create noticable differences in the gameplay. Checkpoint: Thank the devs for creating a lenient save system that allows quick-saving, quick-reloading, and more than a dozen save slots, so every failure doesn't equate to half and hour or more of lost progress.Cons Two Minutes to Finish Test: Unfortunately, the fantastic game ends with a lackluster performance as the ending of the game leaves much to be desired. A Word From Our Sponsors: Even though cutscenes for exposition is unavoidable, there are quite a few long and unskippable cutscenes (especially the one right at the beginning). Achievement Unlocked? If you're an achievement hunter like me, there are quite a few achievements in this game that you can fail with no warning whatsoever. They can happen offscreen in areas you left minutes ago, and there's no way to really anticipate or prevent them.Score: 9.4/10

content:
17, 2014
TL;DR: Already own the original? Don't bother.The original game (meaning Human Revolution - NON director's cut) amused me greatly and I blasted through it in a relatively small amount of hours. So seeing the Director's Cut pop up on Steam for 5 bucks extra made me enthusiastic to replay it. I can't help but feel slightly disappointed. I don't know what I was expecting, but to me personally this updated edition didn't add much replayability. It has a graphic polish, and the boss battles offer more ways to defeat them. But other than that, it seems completely the same game. And I hear you think - "What did you expect? It's only an updated version." True enough, BUT it's an updated version that required another 5 euros for some reason. And 5 euros for an update would, to me at least, suggest a TON of new features, missions and whatnot.So to those that already own the original non-director's cut edition, I don't think it's worth the extra money. However, seeing as this is the only version you can buy on Steam now, people that DON'T already own it should definitely consider because it is a great game in many ways.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
24, 2015
												Before playing this Game, I had never been interested or even a follower of the Deus Ex series. This game changed that. Deus Ex Human Revolution is by far one of my favorite games of all time. The pure aspect of the game being a game almost without a genre is appealing to me. The reason I say a game without a genre, is because the game is open, and literally can be played anyway you want. The progression is stellar, both gameplay and storyline wise. The other thing I like about this game is just how open it is. For example, I had to get into a bar to talk to one of the contacts helping me with a mission, there unfortunately was a bouncer outside who wouldn't let me in. I looked for other entrances, and found one but I had to move a dumpster, and my strength wasn't high enough to move it to let me in, hence I pick up another side mission promising me more piraxis points to level up so then I can revisit the club and continue with my story mission. This is the reason why this game is great, there are literally so many different ways and possibilities of completing your mission it warrant multiple play throughs. On top of all of this, the storyline is fantastic, personally I love the voice acting of Adam Jensen (Elias Toufexious) and his grizzled demenour, and the stroyline is just so thick and rich filled with twists and turns and questions, its a very well put together game. Gameplay, Storyline, and Pacing are some of the things that make this great. I can't wait to see what they'll do in the sequel. The only cons I would list, are that the game isn't the prettiest, I understand this was made a couple years ago, but for example Adam Jensen's hair in game just looks atrocious. Only improvement I would request in the sequel.

content:
3, 2014
												Spectacular game.Approach each situation as either a lethal assassin, stealthy vent-crawler, or an accomplished hacker, discover evidence of the global conspiracy, fight for the truth in this epic 20 hour thriller.What's great about it:1) Captivating story: After the first 2 minutes, the complex plot starts unfolding and you are in the middle of it all. Betrayed and left for dead, you become a cybernetically augmented hero and it is up to you to find out how deep the rabbit hole goes.2) Top-notch gameplay: From crawling and jumping, through armed and melee combat, to hacking of computers and security systems, EVERYTHING is entertaining and well designed. Every combat encounter is enjoyable, every computer system is a unique challenge, every nook and cranny rewards you in some way.3) Branching dialogues with different outcomes: Threaten, beg, reason, humble... be cold or supportive, be enthusiastic or pesimistic - and see how the outcome changes based on your silver tongue.4) Technical aspects: Very good graphics, sprawling city hubs and intricately designed "quest levels", awesome music and realistic sound design - the game has it all.

I realize that I had logged 31 hours into the game already, but a part of me felt like I should only be about halfway through the game.  Yep. That's right. My complaint is that I beat it. Now I'm going into plotline withdrawls.  Seriously, I'd rate this game 12 out of 10.

This game gets a solid 9 out of 10 the only negative factors are the endings and somewhat choppy npc animations

content:
ber 11, 2015
I didn't ask for this...Deus Ex: Human Revolution is what you'd call a modern classic. It's one of the greatest games of our time, and will most likely stand the test of time. I've bought and played through it twice to completion, once on PS3 and now on PC, and the Director's Cut includes the fun and story-adding Missing Link DLC. This game is a worthy addition to any gamer's library, and now I think it's time to explain why. GameplaySurveying the warehouse floor, you see five guards patrolling. You could snatch the shotgun that lies, unattended, in the office, or you could hack the security system that will turn the turret systems against the guards. You could cloak and move silently past them. You could choke or stab each one, dragging them away from sight and picking them off one by one. You could unlock the doors, sneak through the vent, throw a concussion grenade, drop a box on their head... the possibilities are essentially endless. You want to try an approach in this game, go ahead. Sure, the pure combat approach may not be the most fun shooter you've ever played, but the stealth system in this game is great, and the free-form missions enable you to play multiple saves and never have the same experience twice. You can augment your character with a large variety of different augmentations, which all have practical use in many instances throughout the game. There isn't really one that you will regret buying, though, still, spend wisely! The only thing that lets this section down are still the iffy boss fights. There still isn't a true stealth option, at least not to my knowledge. StoryYou play Adam Jensen, security chief of one of America's largest biotech industries. One day, before going to present a new technology to the world, your offices are attacked, and you left for dead. Resurrected by the very biotechnology you protected, Adam now investigates the biggest conspiracy of the 2020s in an effort to bring justice to the people who murdered his friends and coworkers. It's a very good story and excellent mystery. Well worth playing just for the story. Graphics, Atmosphere, and SoundThe graphics are, perhaps, slightly dated, but still look crisp enough that you'll enjoy it. The atmosphere of the game is spot on. Deus Ex paints a future that is worrying, but you'll still think that Adam Jensen looks damned awesome in those augmented shades. The gritty, cyberpunk world is well worth exploring every nook and cranny for. The sound of the game is also spot on. The rattle of the combat rifle, the hiss as you reload the magazine, the subtle footsteps, the idle chatter of the enemies, and who can forget the incredible theme song, Icarus. Another great element to a great game.  Conclusion An rollicking mystery with intriguing plot twists and interesting characters who you can't trust 100%, this game is most definitely worth playing twice, even more than twice... This game isn't perfect, but after all, it was only made by humans...

content:
er 26, 2013
												Still a great game.Lots of choice in how to approach situations, an interesting story and a very good non-lethal option.Graphically, it's distinctive, but texturing, both on characters and the environment, is spotty. While relatively high detail in most cases, it just feels a little amateurish sometimes. Character models also look a little odd, especially for characters that don't play a central part in the story.The orange/gold colour scheme can end up wearing you down too.I've never actually played the game focussing on weapons and combat, choosing the non-lethal route, so I can't comment on how gunplay feels, but stealth options are very satisfying.It is however a very long game, so doesn't lend itself to immediate replays. And this length is punishing if you're chasing achievements, particularly if you're going for one of the ones that relies on a perfect playthrough, such as Pacifist or Foxiest of the Hounds. There's no way of knowing you've failed these achievements until you've completed the game, and the systems can occasionally break beyond your control, potentially costing you the achievement.Still, the journey's a great one and the game deserves to be played

content:
, 2015
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a surprisingly good game.I'd been told it was a good game previously, but never had a chance to try it out. By the time I remembered about the game, it was a few years after release and the graphics looked somewhat dated and I was foolish enough to give the game a skip based on that.Then a friend of mine offered me a spare copy of the game going free, so I thought 'Ack, why the heck not!' and installed with haste. I played it straight over the following three days, putting 25.8 hours into the game, completing it on the hardest difficulty (or at least, the hardest available. I think there might be an even harder level now available after completing the game).Oh boy, it was good.Problem was, I went through the entire game without killing anyone. Or so I thought. Then I remembered I shot someone in the tutorial. Whoops. Oh well, just an achievement.The game was rather easy to play, especially if you play non-lethal ghost. I've not tried out going loud - I suspect it'd be much harder, considering the amount of damage they deal on harder difficulties. So one might want to take that into mind. Gameplay wise the game is above average - it's not exactly a great shooter, but the stealth is decent enough. It could be improved and I hope in the new game they make the combat a little more intuitive and/or realistic. But there will always be more one can want.Yet what makes it great is the world and the story, and how people react to your actions. It feels nice when people comment about your lack of lethal use throughout the game - and, without spoiling anything, saving certain characters also happens to have a significant impact on the game too.Obviously in my review, however basic it may be, I'm biased to a degree because I didn't actually purchase the game - but having played it, I would've bought it (at sale price, because I'm stingy) had I know what the game was actually like to player.P.S. IlluminatiP.S.S. Thanks Zero!

content:
er 17, 2016
												This game was a love letter to the very first Deus Ex released way back in the year 2000 when The Matrix film was making waves in the science fiction community. HR follows almost the same plot as the first Deus Ex from the beginning, but thankfully HR has the benefit of modern gameplay.My favourite part of the game was using stealth to execute completely unnoticed "instant takedowns" (aka punching 1 or 2 dudes so hard that they were permanently knocked unconscious). The real challenge was hiding their sleeping bodies so that no other enemies would find and wake them.It was very easy to exploit this game's AI. I once lured 5 guards to the second floor just by running and jumping around. I laid them out unconscious side by side. You'd think they'd have radios for their commanding officer to check in! However, this is not a drawback. Rather, you can exploit the AI in many, many creative and funny ways, just like the first Deus Ex.Overall this game had the right balance of action, drama and humour. I recommend this game to anyone, not just Deus Ex fans.

content:
3, 2014
												Spectacular game.Approach each situation as either a lethal assassin, stealthy vent-crawler, or an accomplished hacker, discover evidence of the global conspiracy, fight for the truth in this epic 20 hour thriller.What's great about it:1) Captivating story: After the first 2 minutes, the complex plot starts unfolding and you are in the middle of it all. Betrayed and left for dead, you become a cybernetically augmented hero and it is up to you to find out how deep the rabbit hole goes.2) Top-notch gameplay: From crawling and jumping, through armed and melee combat, to hacking of computers and security systems, EVERYTHING is entertaining and well designed. Every combat encounter is enjoyable, every computer system is a unique challenge, every nook and cranny rewards you in some way.3) Branching dialogues with different outcomes: Threaten, beg, reason, humble... be cold or supportive, be enthusiastic or pesimistic - and see how the outcome changes based on your silver tongue.4) Technical aspects: Very good graphics, sprawling city hubs and intricately designed "quest levels", awesome music and realistic sound design - the game has it all.

content:
14, 2014
												Oh, where to begin?  Deux Ex is a decent game, blending concepts of stealth, shooting, and social engineering.  Unfortunately, it doesn't really excel in any area.  The stealth sequences are very old-fashioned, in that they work well enough if you choose to stay concealed but fall apart badly if you prefer to kill quietly.  The shooting mechanics are hindered by poor controls - left trigger dives for cover instead of aiming down sights, etc - and by guns that just don't feel good.  It's great that the weapons can be upgraded in all manner of ways, but it's all for naught if they don't feel good to shoot.  Case in point: the round from a sniper rifle shouldn't drop in flight by 18 inches during a 25 yard shot.  Also, a guy that gets hit in the head with a finger-long projectile traveling at roughly 700 mph shouldn't immediately snap to attention and try to figure out who shot him just because he's wearing a helmet.  Finally, the parts of the game that attempt to challenge players by way of dialogue choices feels like LA Noire - the clues and responses that you're given don't correspond very tightly to the desired outcomes; two players making the same choices won't necessarily get the same result - it's stupid.All that said, the game features an intriguing story and is good enough (barely) at what it does to be worth playing.  The director's cut (poorly) incorporates the Missing Link DLC into the main campaign and adds some optional DVD-style commentary.  Unfortunately, because the upgrade exists as a separate title in the Steam library no saved games or achievements carry over into the new game.  I'd say that it's worth grabbing, but only if you don't already own The Missing Link.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2016
												Up to this day this game is my favorite. Honestly, I have never fully understood why do I like this game so much. Bash me if you want to, but I can't say it's perfect in every possible detail. The thing is, it's not about the details themselves, it's about them being being knit together so good you're getting absorbed by the game as it's going, making it one of the most immersive games in the world. Everything -  story, gameplay, lore, characters, world around you, even the damn yellow filter functions so well together you get a feeling it's not even a made up story but something that WILL happen at some point, that's how good this game is. You're seriosly starting to question yourself about the events that did not happen, but they FEEL like they did. You feel like you're in control of your character, it's you making it happening. It's applaudable on how Eidos Montreal made a protagonist with a personality, yet completely relatable in the things he's (or you're) doing. This is what Deus Ex: Human Revolution is for me, and I totally recommend you playing it.

												I spent more than 50 hours playing this game on the PS3, now on the PC and I will keep playing it until Mankind Divided hits the market. People who complain about this game have clearly not taken the time to look at all its details. Human Revolution has a rich story and a very good gameplay. The characters are interesting (although they sometimes have pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ animations, but *shrugs*), the main character is awesome and has a very interesting character design, I LOVE his german voice. I think the english one sounds too... rough, emotionless and monotonous, if not even bored. I loved the level designs, loved the different locations... And, like I said, the story is... wow. It does not happen often, but I am able to play this game again and again without getting bored of the story. The conspiracies, the stuff you learn about transhumanism,... Seriously. People who think this game sucks, clearly have no time to explore the whole world of Deus Ex: Human Revolution. I have hacked nearly every computer in the game, read all E-Books and PDAs. Most people seem to forget that it is in fact a Roleplaying Game. Not a CoD like "let me shoot everything that comes in front of my gun". A RPG is about exploring the world. If you have no time for that, then you should probably have a look at other game genres :)

content:
ber 3, 2016
												The dev team thought of everything.Other reviews can praise this game's stealth, combat, upgrades, art, characters, and story, I just want to show my appreciation for the sheer amount of player choice in this game. Sometimes I was flabbergasted after a mission, going back through the level and realizing just how impressive its design was in terms of making sure that you can get through it ANY way you want to. Pacifict? Check. Terminator? Check. Hacker? Scavenger? Little-of-everything? All of the above. I loved it.And more than just the amount of choice was the implementation. I've said in other reviews that what I want in a game is one where the challenge comes from fighting the bad guys, not from fighting the controls. 99% of everything I tried in this game was a fair challenge. No shoddy, sloppy work. I push the button; thing happens the way it's supposed to. And there were plenty of times when I had a nutty idea and thought, 'Can I do that?' Yes I could. Punch civilians in the head! Throw turrets into the sea! Make modern art with piles of unconscious enemies! Steal EVERYTHING!My only real complaint was with the implanted DLC. While I did grow to enjoy it by the end, (especially Quinn), at times it felt uneccesary and shoehorned in, and there were parts when the writing was bizarrely sexist. Oh well. Once I got off the boat it was back to the main game and everything was fine again.Overall, DXHR is going in my favorites list. I look forward to New Game+. The D-Row Ballers won't know what hit 'em.P.S. Major congrats to Adam Jensen's voice actor. The Neo-esque gravelly growl could have easily been monotone and emotionless, but he managed to put a ton of subtle personality into the performance. Often through taking the lines as read, and knowing exactly which words to punch emphasis into. Kudos!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 12
												It's been a good 13 years or so since first I played the (amazing) Deus Ex and attempted to go back to back with the Deus Ex sequel, Invisble War. Yeah, that didn't go so well. Deus Ex featured open ended, globe trotting goodness  while IW felt like a crappy console port. Thankfully the third game in the series, Human Revolution, has rediscovered the original's roots and paves it's own way into excellence. I'm not going to go into the story of DE: HR becuase frankly the story is lengthy, complicated and is ever changing depending on your decisions. But don't let that scare you off because it is absolutely engrossing. I'd refer to DE: HR more as a "First Person RPG". Gameplay is at it's best when you're sneaking around, diagnosing, and using your brain to find ways around situations. It's especially satisfying when you have robot or turret domination. Press the button to get them on your side and listen to chaos ensue. However, if you're looking to gun your way through this game I'd say you'll be disappointed. The shooting is extremely "eh" and even with your armor maxed, the enemies will be able to take more damage than you.  Also kind of on the eh side is everything really looks the same. You'll be inside most of the time crawling through corridors, sewers and air vents. WAY more to like though. The soundtrack is great and overall the voice acting is as well. There are so many solutions to the problems in this game, even if you're underpowered you'll get through it. The campaign is incredibly lengthy and there are tons of side missions for you to do. I wholeheartedly recommend DE: HR but I can see why this game wouldn't be for everyone.  As long as you aren't expecting a CoD one man army style of shooter it's hard to imagine you'd be disappointed. 9/10 from me.

												I like how I put nearly 40 hours into this game and only have 64% of the achievements. I love exploration, decisions matter, supports multiple playstyles- type games, and this is a solid one. I had no problem at all running it on my computer.The only thing I really didn't like is that in an RPG, I should care about the characters. They should have personalities and stories and their lives and deaths should matter to me. I didn't get that here. I didn't care what happened to any of them- not Megan, Sarif, Malik, Pritchard, or even Jensen. So, after a while, all I wanted to do was kill everyone and get the game over with.Also, the integration of the DLC was very jarring to me.So, while it's not an experience I will cherish forever after its end like some other games, the combat and the plot are just engaging enough that the ride is worth it.

While your actions in a given quest don't have the biggest impact on the overall story, the freedom and possible resolutions available within any given quest is pretty impressive. Gameplay is pretty solid; it's slower and more tactical than your average shooter, but it's executed well and blends great with the tone of the game world.The Director's Cut has some great improvements over the original, the most notable being turning off the Jarate filter, redesigning the boss fights to allow for a variety of approaches instead of forcing you into cover-shooting regardless of what your playstyle thus far was, and including the expansion as an in-built portion of the story.

content:
, 2015
												I upgraded a pistol with a silencer and a laser pointer and used that as a sniper gun. 10/10Deus Ex: HR is a slightly older game (~2011) that tackles the question of makind's future and human augmentation. Set in 2027 across various locations including Detroit and Hengsha, it shows a possible future for humanity. Poverty, gangs, and protesters ranging from anti-augmentation "purists" to environmentalists all paint a sharp contrast to the scientific progress, the wealthy few who can affort augmentations, and corporations that have replaced governments.The main protagonist, an ex-SWAT chief security guard with a voice similar to the sound of sandpaper, feels a bit forced, as if he were only here to let the story develop. After mercenaries attack his workplace at Sarif Industries, his life is saved by augmentations, and he becomes a one-man army. His boss sends him on missions where he either sneaks by everyone to steal important information or shoots everyone down and steals important information. As you may have guessed, this is a mix between a stealth and an FPS game. Stealth as in the Thief series' 2014 reboot, entitled Thief, and FPS as in games where you gun everyone down.To make the gameplay work, you are given a choice on how you want to get to your objective -- the pewpewpew approach, the stealthy one-by-one takedown approach and the sneak by everyone through the vents approach are the main three ways of dealing with situations. Sometimes, an approach (especially the latter two) will require you to upgrade your character with augmentations. The upgrade system works, though some features are completely redundant, as your approaches may not require that augmentation (which is perfectly normal for this kind of upgrade system), or the character can already do what the upgrade enables him to do (such as some of the hacking-oriented augmentations).I can't really find anything to complain about. The story was interesting, though at times a bit forced, and the lack of a definitive antagonist just makes the game feel messy -- you are a single man fighting against the Illuminati. Pritchard and David Sarif are both c*nts in their own ways, and character movement during dialogues is glitchy, repetitive, and unnatural. But that's all that's wrong with the game, and those are minor details that don't take away from the experience.tl;dr: I liked the game and have played it twice (only once through Steam). I've often seen it on sale, and one playthrough is worth at least 20 hours if you don't rush everything, pick the more peaceful approaches, and complete a few side missions.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 16, 2016
												Stealth games have lately sucked, mainly for the simple reason that you’re too damn strong and the game keeps telling you that killing them is wrong when they would do it right away if they had a chance. It makes games such as Dishonored kinda suck as I personally don’t even feel like playing on a stealthy way when you can just kill them on one hit and they’ll take minutes and dozens of men to do the same thing to you. That’s different on Deus Ex. I wasn’t the biggest fan of the first game as it was overly confusing and too complex when I first got it over 10 years ago, I was young and I couldn’t get a liking to it… But when I grew up, I played the living f#ck of it. So sure I would get this game. I got the normal one, I got the DLC, and I even got the Director’s Cut Edition. Is it worth it? As usual I’m gonna start by what it does wrong.First and foremost, the animations. I’m not sure why, but I just can’t get a liking to most NPC’s animations. They look stiff and really forced, specially at the start of the game. Hostile NPC’s do look believable, but friendly NPC’s keep acting like robots, lots of them even reusing the same animations like you wouldn’t notice.Something I also found somewhat annoying are the boss fights. Now hear me here, they were A BILLION TIMES WORSE BEFORE. On the original game, you had to fight bosses on a lethal way, no matter if you’re playing on a stealthy hacking way or guns blazing, it was a big gameplay flaw that could seriously ruin stealth runs. It was somewhat fixed on the Director’s Cut by giving a few different options such as using turrets to do it for you, but it’s still weak. It could have been way better.Another thing I didn’t like were the endings. On a game this damn long, around 20 hours of good story and gameplay, WHILE IN THE ACTUAL #NAL F#CK SH#T DO ALL ENDINGS JUST TURN INTO STOCK FOOTAGE WITH A VOICE-OVER!? It’s the laziest sh#t ever! It TRULY feels like you’ve accomplished NOTHING. Lastly, the hacking minigame is a bit too random at times. You start it to get a door open, suddenly it starts flashing red colors on a 25% detection checkpoint and you’re WAAAAY too far away to get there in time. If you go into a stealth run and are forced to hack stuff, you better stock on viruses. You’ll need them if you’re unlucky.Taking the trash out however, we do find quite a few gems on the game.Where the game shines the most is the gameplay. Remember the comparison to other stealth games such as Dishonored? Here you truly can do it however you feel like, and it TRULY feels like it makes a difference. In Dishonored it barely changes the last levels and gives you a different ending cinematic, while here taking the brutal guns-blazing option from the start makes others question if what you’re doing is right.I also like how weapons work. Lethal or non-lethal, you can upgrade them throughout the game and turn a sh#tty generic pistol into a death-sentence that has a silencer, can work through armor like it’s warm butter and has 25 bullet magazines. At the same time though, the game never gives you too much ammo of one thing, usually only giving you two or three bullets out of enemies you’ve taken out, making you actually take aim and be careful on whatever the hell you’re doing with your fancy toys. That also somewhat expands to augmentations. Throughout the game you’ll get Praxis thingies that can be used to make your character better in a good variety of ways. Want to be invisible for short durations of time? Want to see through walls? Want to jump higher? Want to be immune to fall damage? Want to have a better aim when shooting? Want to make less to no noise when walking or running? Want to pick up a fridge and shove it up someone’s #ss? It’s all there, and you choose what to do.The voice-acting and music department is actually quite a big point on this game. Everyone sounds real, truly immersed on their role on the big story the game has. Specially the main character who, although a bit clichéd and being a bit parody to Robocop, is likable and quite a badass.The game also offers a good variety of ways to get to the desired objective… Except with bosses as I’ve already said. Even on Stealth runs, there’s usually multiple ways to get there, it’s all up to you to find them.Also, the game shows some Dev foresight as they got NPC’s ready to react to things you might have not expect to. You steal everything from the building you’re working at as security chief? People will send you emails complaining about multiple thefts happening. People give you a quest about taking out drug lords you’ve already executed and dunked their face to the ground? They’ll call you out on it. These kinds of things are quite unexpected and funny as hell.Do I recommend this game? Yeah! It’s a really good experience which truly gives you freedom to do whatever you feel like. It has a good length, the DLC’s already added to the game and it’s a fun experience. The bosses suck, but that’s a low price against a good amount of great content. You might have never asked for this, but you should give it a try.TL;DR Edition: A good example of a stealth game. Boss fights kinda still suck, but offers tons of variety on a quite long experience. Would totally recommend on a sale. IT TRULY IS A BOMB!

content:
y 31, 2014
												TL;DR at the endWell well, what can i say?I LOVE THIS GAME.It's probably one of the few games that I bought without knowing much about it and ended up being a real gem. I bought the original game on sale for 2€ more or less and played until the end, very good game, but I didn't enjoyed completely since I went for the pacifist achievement (not a single person should die by you hand) so i couldn't see the real awesomeness of Deus Ex HR, I also failed the achievement... so sad :( After a while the director's cut pops up, with HD textures, new weapons, reworked boss battles (that was much needed), a DLC, but I like to call it an expansion, since it's not the usual DLCrap and a developers commentary. The best thing about this new edition is that it really shows how much effort was put in by the devs, every aspect of the game shows enthusiasm and dedication to the creation and improvement of the game. Let's talk about specific stuff (I like this part)***Graphics*** 9/10 The graphics was already good from the beginning, but now, whith the improved textures, is even better. The pattern on Adam's coat is one of the first thing you will notice, that floral embroidery is simply amazing. Attention to the details is something that won't go unnoticed when you play the game, from the beginning to the end. When you are talking with someone you can see their facial expression changing, depending on the way you approach them, try not to make people angry or the might not share valuable information. The only thing i can say against this topic it that the graphic seems a bit beneath the level of other games that came out that year (2011), but it's nothing to be worried about, it's a 10 in my opinion, but I can't help myself comparing it to Arkham City (that one was a 10/10 that year).***Sound*** 10/10 Yep, ten, the music is perfect, no other words. It's impressive, the atmosphere of the environment and the music go arm in arm. For what concerns the sound effects, I have nothing to say except that everything feels right, especially when using your augmentation powers to punch through a concrete wall and break the neck of the poor guy on the other side. Wanna talk about voice acting? Absolutely fantastic, all of them, dubbers really made it big.***Story*** 10/10 This game is a movie, there is so much in the story that will keep you glued to your PC, so many secrets to uncover that you know people are keeping from you, but the game just won't give you ... yet. You need to reach the very end to know the truth and when the moment arrives the only thing you can say is "OH...MY...GOD! How could I've been so blind this whole time?!"***Gameplay*** 11/10 Am I crazy ? Yes, ELEVEN. Depending on which skill you purchase you can complete missions in different ways, which sometimes drastically change the game itself. Each mission has a lot of different approaches, let's say you need to go from point A to point B, ok? You can go Rambo style, if you're a fan of slaughter, or you can buy the stealth upgrades to become invisible and silent, if you like to sneak past guards and catch them with their pants down, or you could look for a security terminal to hack and be granted the access to point B, or you could even enter a vent shaft and sneak inside metal tunnels all the way through, sometimes you can even take shortcuts by punching walls creating nice holes ... and a bit of a mess, but who cares. So yes there are at least 4 or 5 different approaches for every mission and this is the best thing about this game, freedom.***BONUS(ES) of the Director's cut edition***+ Replayable, with the option to keep the progress from the previous game+ HD textures+ If you already own the basic game you get a discount on the director's cut, even more discount if you own the dlc+ A DLC with an amazing story and some surprise for the fans of the original Deus EX+ New weapons+ 280, more or less, commentary from the develeopers that explains everything about the making of Deus Ex HR+++ Reworked boss battles. This need a little explanation, in the original game these battles were really bad, and with really bad I mean they were total crap. You sneaked past every guard with your ninja skills, but then you reached a boss that you could only take down with brute force. Finally, the devs realized the error and created new ways to kill these enemies, of course you can still nuke the **** out of them, but hacking the computer that controls sentry turrets or that release a powerful toxic gas... well, that is really praiseworthy. This shows how much a company that make games cares about players, for this improvement I say BRAVO! to the devs.TL;DR Game's kicks major asses, if you don't play it you're missing a milestone of the videogame industry.

content:
er 25, 2013
												(For those of you wondering whether this is a version of Human Revolution with Montreal and/or Upper Hengsha city hubs: sorry, this isn't it.  At this point, I doubt it'll ever come our way, at least barring a "Super Director's Cut" edition.  Don't be waiting for it.)The DE:HR Director's Cut integrates The Missing Link, a previously standalone story, into the original game, and adds in a New Game Plus mode which carries over all abilities (but no items, sadly) from a completed playthrough.  Some preorder-bonus missions are also added in, but the best addition here is a stellar commentary from the biggest names behind the game.  Seriously - give it a listen.  There's a ton of it (about 8 hours total), but quite a bit of it is insightful and interesting.  A new gold standard for commentary in video games (sorry Valve).Newcomers: this is an absolute steal for twenty bucks.  A playthrough of the Director's Cut will take you anywhere from 35-60 hours, depending on how much you see and do, and it's just a flat-out great game besides.  The art direction, soundtrack, and story are first-rate, as are the scenarios that accommodate a range of playstyles the Deus Ex universe is renowned for supporting.  Whether you try to sneak, hack, or shoot your way through this universe, it's a good time.

content:
10, 2014
												It's everything the original game was and more. It's got all the DLC (Including Missing Link) preinstalled and neatly weaseled into the main story so it's really just one fluid playthrough of the entire game. I've played some 45 hours which got me two full playthroughs (one for fun and one for achievement-whoring) and an additional four playthroughs of the Missing Link-part because I'm an idiot and forgot that automatic unlocking devices count as grenades, when I was trying to get "Factory Zero".Anyways, I've read a lot of crap on the forums about people having absolutely TERRIBAD framerates with this version of the game, so if you do not want the commentary and don't really care about playing it all in a fluid playthrough, then you can get the original + DLC instead.Personally I find this version way superiour because of what is mentioned above, and for the fact that you now have options for fighting the bosses. You don't HAVE to invest in combat skills in order to beat them. Much appreciated!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												The Director's Cut offers some enhancements over the original version as well as Developers Commentary and Making of footage. Among the new features are the improvements in Boss Fight where you are not limited or forced to front armed combat, and the integration of The Missing Link DLC.Putting the Director's Cut tag to a side, and having played on Normal, I must admit I was faced with one of the dumbest AI. The story, cliched as it is, it's also interesting enough to get you hooked the whole game. Controls are awkward as shooting mechanics, but once you get used to them it becomes a much enjoyable experience.Graphics are very nice, and characters are coupled with good quality voice acting, but it's in the music department where this title really shines. Character leveling and the choices you make give replayability to the different stages and situations.In short, nothing too outstanding, but in spite of it's flaws I still recommend this game. After all, it's surely in the top 10 of AAA titles of the year.Edit: Added screenshots.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2013
												I did not know Deus Ex before i saw it on Steam. I purchased this game because it was on sale, cost only $4.99. I watch some trailers and reviews reckoned i could give it a shot. And gladly its worth the money. For starters, this game is somewhat like Mass effect + Dishonored hybrid, assuming you know both these games. You might not agree, anyways its just my opinion. But be warned, to me this isint quite a shooter game. It's an FPS, it has got a handful of guns and you can shoot things as shown in the trailer but most of the times you'll be doing lots of stealth, hiding behind covers trying to sneak past enemies. Sounds pretty familiar? (Hitman). Well if you dont like the stealth approach, you could go gun blazing, but i dont think this is the way this game is meant to be played, especially during the first half of the story which is after llike 10+ hours of gameplay (for me) mainly because you could be easily outgunned. Of course you could jump right infront of the enemies and shoot them in the face tough later in the game prior to sufficent upgrade of your carecter.So..... If you are looking for fast-paced shooter like COD, your wont get it. Its a slow-paced game involved lots of thinking as in how do i get past this, how do i access that, something like that. If you're in it for the story telling and RPG experience then i recommend you to grab it. The voice acting might not be fantastic but it works and it surely gave me a somewhat unique experience that not many games could offer.I'd love to give it a 9/10 but -1 for the graphics/visuals, so it's 8/10 ! Dont get me wrong, its graphics aren't crappy at all, is just that i adore better ones.

content:
ber 10, 2016
												PROS:- Great atmosphere, full of interesting characters and intense social commentary.- Playing stealth and non-lethal is rewarding, adds additional challenge to an otherwise standard FPS game.- New Game+ allows for repeat playthroughs with all of your previous upgrades allowing for different outcomes.CONS:- Random stuttering near tight areas and walls, even at high settings. It’s annoying, but bearable.- Boss fights can be laughably easy near the end, offering little challenge.- Heavy backtracking is required for several Side Missions, making the world feel grindy.Fans of the action-stealth genre will find plenty to enjoy in Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut. The boss fights have been reworked to include alternative ways to win. New Game+ can extend the life of the game for additional replayability. Other than some graphical hitches, buying this game on sale is one of the best value you can get.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2013
												This game is a monumental achievement, a unique singleplayer experience combining FPS elements with stealth, puzzles and a complex and engaging story.The atmosphere created by the impeccable graphic design, good voice acting and stunning soundtrack is truly memorable. The game world is crafted masterfully and in great detail: from the essential characters that are interesting and flawed to the futuristic settings for the intriguing tehcno thriller of a story, the player is treated with such quality and class that only a few games do. The game offers an astounding amount of information and small details for the player to consume (should they be so inclined).The levels and character customization provide the player with a number of options to achieve the goal in any given mission and indeed DX:HRDC is one of the very few first person games that actually offer the player multiple ways to finish the game. Moreover, depending on player choice the mission outcomes may vary significantly and the story unfold in a different manner. If you explore the world and finish side quests it will probably take around 25 - 35 hours to finish the game. The new Director's Cut edition integrates the Missing Link DLC seamlessly into the main game in addition to which it also comes with a "making of" documentary, commentary mode, a new game+ option and a host of other changes and tweaks. DX:HRDC is the best version of the game yet and a truly epic experience that should not be missed!

y 24, 2014
												For those looking to upgrade from the original:The advertised boss fight upgrades are good if you want to experiment, but if you've played the game before you'll probably have more praxsis points than you can handle and know the best way to take these bosses down.  It's mostly for the newcomers, not for you.  The integration with all the DLC is a bit better too.  You don't get all the DLC weapons straight away like before but they're still present in-game.For those newcomers:It is a GREAT way for those looking to get into Stealth games.  It is easy to pick up and challenging to master while still not making things EXCLUSIVELY stealth-oriented.  The dialogue battles are also pretty great and tense, and I was amazed to see how they weren't just "do these options in this order".  It does really well at giving you a variety of choices, whether they be diplomatic or aggressive.  The aesthetics are fantastic, the voicework is great (perhaps a few hiccups with the foreign characters), and the overall gameplay is really fun and not repetitive.A must-buy for all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												First, some reviewers on here did not recommend this title because they claimed it was buggy. I did not experience a single bug from my 30 hour playthrough so I am not quite sure as to what they were referring to. As far as the DLC that comes with this title: the DLC mission is integrated so seamlessly into the main story that I didn't even realize it was the DLC until after I had completed the game. I think the best part about Deus Ex: Human Revolution is it literally allows you to play the game however you wish. Do you enjoy complete stealth missions and sneaking around? You can do that and there are weapons designed specifically for stealth (tranquilizers and stun guns for example). Do you enjoy running in and blowing up everyone you see with a rocket launcher? You can do that too. You have special augmentations that you choose to unlock in order to play the game to your style. For example you can unlock short bursts of invisibility in order to avoid being seen; or if you choose to fight you can augment hand to hand combat and weapon abilities. The game is designed so that you, the player, are given the ability to choose exactly how you play the game.As far as the story goes, it was good/above average but not amazing. It felt extremely rabbit holey. The rabbit hole went down so far that I just kept thinking to myself "welp, I guess I'll find the bottom around 50 hours in." The story has a lot of twists and turns, but none of them are particularly interesting. It was just like, ok, you found out something new, better go check it out.. and down the rabbit hole you go. Rinse and repeat. But it was never an overly interesting rabbit hole. On the flipside, the ending is simply one of the best endings I have experienced. It reminds you of just how empowering, yet brutally dangerous technology can be to society. To quote Einstein: "Technological progress is like an axe in the hands of a pathological criminal."Overall, the gameplay is one of the best I've experienced. The story mixes technology and the choices it forces on human morality. This title is close to perfection in both terms of gameplay and story, and I can't give the developers enough praise. Deus Ex: Human Revolution takes about 20 hours playtime to finish, and about 30 hours if you do all the side missions. 9.5/10Please upvote this review if you found it useful :)

												It's one of those very few games that are mixing together different gameplay elements in the right way.Deus Ex is a Stealth-RPG-FPS-Action lore heavy game. It is really standing out in every aspect and everything is executed in the right way.The story is great, varied, with many twists. The characters are memorable, layered, the conversations feel very natural, the writing is awesome. There are many moral choices and all lead to different conclusions. Queasts, sidequests, different collectibles, reading materials. You can solve missions in many ways, somewhat reminding you of games like the Hitman series just in a Cyberpunk enviroment. Yep you can be like Hulk, Rambo, Leon the professional, or Sam Fisher to tackle your missions, using your enviroment in many different ways.I strongly recomend this game to any gamer regardless of what type of game you like to play, it feels like there si something and everything for anyone here.

content:
y 15, 2015
												If you're like me - old - you played the first Deus Ex and you found it amazing. So when you approached Deus Ex: HR you probably thought: "This stinks, the first one is obviously better, they don't make good videogames anymore blah blah".Well my friend you're wrong, because Deus Ex: HR is a pleasure. Gameplay wise it's ok, it's more hide-and-shoot than I hoped it to be, but it plays smooth and you quickly find yourself breezing through vents like solid snake. Graphics are good: not amazing, but the areas are full of details. Great care was used during the design - especially the city hubs. They are basically the same stuff, yet they FEEL so different.The story and the environment are legendary. I'm not gonna talk about it, because I haven't finished it yet and because everything is a major spoiler, but the environment is really, REALLY immersive.The conflict between people seeing augmentations as progress, and the ones seeing them as something that curses you to live under medications for the rest of your life is excellent. Whenever you feel you're doing something right, something else happens and you're all like: "What if I was wrong all along...?"This, THIS is what Deus Ex: HR is all about for me. The struggle, the insecurity, the feeling you COULD do something for someone, but you're never sure if you SHOULD do it.A beautiful game so far. Feels just like the original. And the protagonist is quite likeable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 13, 2016
												I've promised myself muitiple times that the next playthrough was the last, but no, I had to play it several more times that I've lost count. In fact, I might even play it again several more times, even if I'll follow the same mindset/route(s). Hell, I might even discover a new route or two, or even a cache of items. With this in mind, each playthrough may or may not be similar depending on how you go on about it. In fact, certain paths might even trigger some dialogue, give you a better vantage point, lead to a shortcut, or even all three.So the Director's Cut adds the DLCs released for the game and some changes for the boss fights as well. The Missing Link story is implimented into the game instead of seperate from it entirly. This adds at least 3~5-ish hours to a somewhat long game. Though I haven't played the original version of the game, I can't really tell you the differences in glitches or visuals, so I'm leaving that out.Gameplay falls under the stealth and action genres, so You can go in guns blazing, stealth kill eveyone(or just a few), or go full pacifist, but you still have to kill the bosses to progress the story though. I find it easier to just kill off everyone as stealthily as possible before I get caught, or just use the cloak augment and book it for next area.Overall, the game is great. I look forward to my future playthroughs even though the experience might get stale but I don't mind. I'll give this game a 9/10, but why a 9? because it can feel a bit slow at times (obviously because its a stealth game of course). But don't let that deter you, that's just from my experience. If you are still on the fence with it, just think it through. Buy it when it's on sale if you're still not sure so it's not a waste of twenty bucks if you regrete it.

ber 10, 2016
												Well where do i start!i was fortunate to be introduced to the Deus ex world back in the day when my old boss bought the game and after just 10 minuites of playing actually stood up and took the cd out of the drive and threw it at me saying 'you can have this load of ****! buzzing i took the game and ran home as soon as i could (i was 16!) and bypassed various security doors and traversed many vents (in my mind) and literly did not come up for air until my brain could not take any more FPS!Wow i was reboarn and my new fav game was deus ex. as the years passed i installed every mod you can imagine for the original game and i beleave i have completed the game over 20 time! next came invisible war, although not n where as solid as the original deus ex i enjoyed it.This brings me onto this gem of a game... when i heard the news of next installment of Deus ex human revolutions i promptly place all my family members on ebar so i could raise the money for the game!What followed was pure bliss..I was welcomed by a deep well thoughtout storyline with in my opinion impecable gameplay.From the hud to the small details you find during your journey through this inmense world.The praxis system and upgrading system was similar to the first titel but managed to up the ante just a little. The storyline is compelling and never in my opinion lets you down.The locations again match the storyline to a T and the options you are presented with regarding the aproach to every level or map in the game are what will keep this game everlasting and replayable over and over againto summerise if i could recommend any game out there to new players to the franchise or our old friends returning to this title i would highly recommend dues ex human revolutions. i would even go so far as to invent a machine to wipe my memory just so i can play it again from fresh!100/10 !!! stop waisting time reading more reviews and buy this game in all of its glory.ps - i only have 16.5 hours in game on steam but i have owned the game on original PC version for ages.PPs- i know this i a little naugthy but i just carnt help myself... After like the majority of the steam community waiting for 5 years for mankind devived i am sad to see and read the reviews. I have not played the game and unfortunately i have not bought the game due to the negative feedback it has been given. I activly return to the forum everyday hopeing for some positive reviews or for some kind of wonder patch to be applyed but sadly i now for over 2 weeks has been the same story...I am probley like stan in eminem regarding deus ex and as i will not be purchasing mankind divided until the issues are changed i cannot post a review on the manking divided forums.I have my 50e waiting for things to change or i will simply buy human revolutions for someone unfortunate to be able to afford it so i can bring a little happiness to someone and introduce them to heaven on earth.peaceShootme

												Even though I already own DXHR and the DLC, I bought this because they fixed a number of things.  First they combined the DLC into the game which makes sense as the DLC shows what happens to you after you leave Hengsha in the stasis tube.  Then (and this is the big one) they fixed the three boss fights.  If you set up Jensen as a brawler and killing isn't an issue, then these fights weren't a big deal.  But if you prefer an emphasis on stealth and electronic surveillance and prefer a more pacifistic approach, then you may have had some issues.Since I already had the game and the DLC, I only paid $5 which is about $5 more than I should have paid for a bugfix.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
"IT'S NOT THE END OF THE WORLD, BUT YOU CAN SEE IT FROM HERE"Deus Ex: Human Revolution (more especifically the Director's Cut) was one of my first games on Steam. A gift, I was actually a bit hesitant on accepting as I've never been a big fan of FPS. The RPG part made me go through the download size and didn't quite prepare me for the stealth. I believe it's more accurate to call DX:HR a stealth with FPS and RPG elements, as the first is the most proeminent trait.As Adam Jensen, you're tasked with security in Sarif Inustries, a top notch corporation specialized in augmentations. Not too long after you started, however, the matrix (located in a 2027 Detroit) is attacked by a mysterious black ops squad and a number of questions rise as you're basically resuscitated by your employer. Seems like your typical cyberpunk setting, except it feels more realistic, more relatable. The secrets you come to know during Adam's journey for answers and revenge easily get you involved while one question is answered and another one is made. And as any person asking the dangerous questions, Adam does so mostly in the shadows. Even though the game offers a large range of strategical approaches and paths, the stealth mechanic can be more rewarding and fulfilling, not to mention lore friendly. On higher difficulties keeping a low profile is actually necessary as augmentations aren't enough to withstand a bulletstorm. Fear not, though, as you can literally be a ghost by taking full advantage of the incredible level design!Not only the story is well written and filled with branches, but the artwork and soundtrack are some of the most relatable and beautiful in recent game history. The architecture feels unique and real, while the soundtrack tries to unite a feeling of old and new by mixing classic notes with electronic beats. It's easy to dive into Deus Ex's universe and get lost in its mature themes, such as transhumanism.Even though the experience is one worth having, it's still far from perfect. The Director's Cut came with a number of performance issues and bugs that -- after almost four years of the game's first release -- haven't yet been fixed by the developers. The game performers poorly on computers above its rcommended specifications and fixing it is no easy task. Still to this day there's no definitive method for AMD users to get completely rid of stuttering and small FPS drops, not to mention a proper (official or from the community) fix for the various bugs that lurk around the corners -- one of which got me frustrated and made me leave the game aside for more than a year. This might be one of those cases where you have to ignore the performance issues to fully enjoy the game, as DX:HR-DC is not a proper PC title/port.Pros:  Friendly to newcomers of the franchise  Very sharp stealth mechanics aligned with a decent AI  RPG elements with the augmentations upgrades  The player is not constantly forced to make use of the FPS mechanics  Large variety of paths and strategies within a single level  Intelligent hacking mechanic  Immersive cyberpunk setting with a deep story, mature context and complex, relatable characters  Beautiful design and soundtrack  Hard and meaningful choices that matter  Multiple endings  Adam's dark pastCons:  Performance issues  Bugs -- lots of them  AMD users might have more difficulty in fixing problems  No "auto-sort" in the inventory  Too many endings (a total of twelve)If you like cyberpunk themes and stealth games, Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a safe bet. And even if you're not particularly interested in what the game has to offer, it might surprise you!

You have the option to either kill the enemies like a killing machine(literally) or sneak around like a ninja. Difficulty is okay at first and then they slowly raise it as you unlock more and more augmentations, and some parts require you to think hard and make use of the objects in your environment if you want to be a ninja.
