content:
, 2014
DISCLAIMER: Don't get fooled by many negative reviews, most of them compare Director's Cut to the original. Original, however, doesn't seem to be available on Steam anymore, so if you've never played it, this is your best (and only) chance!Now, let's get on with the review.Never played Human Revolution? - Get it!Already played HR, should I get Director's Cut? - Got money to spare? Want trading cards/badges? Missed DLC? Sure, go for it. Otherwise, not really. Pros- amazing story- dialogue and other choices have effects later on- you can choose stealth and not kill a single enemy or go on an all-out killing spree. You can also combine those two approaches- multiple solutions to various situations- custom select your abilities (augmentations) to fit your playstyle- a lot of playtime for purely single-player experience (first playthrough is likely going to take you 20-30 hours, how many single-player games offer that nowadays?)Cons- a lot of moving between objectives and your sprinting doesn't last all that long(Wow, that's all I could come up with. I may add some more later but right now, I can't seem to think of anything else that could bother someone. Note: See the Differences section below for potential cons)Differences between regular and Director's Cut [+/-]+ re-worked bossfights, making them less harsh on players who choose stealth + integrated DLC- colors seem washed out, can be fixed with ENB- may encounter some performance issues and/or bugs. Personally, I didn't notice any but maybe I'm just lucky.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
14, 2014
												Oh, where to begin?  Deux Ex is a decent game, blending concepts of stealth, shooting, and social engineering.  Unfortunately, it doesn't really excel in any area.  The stealth sequences are very old-fashioned, in that they work well enough if you choose to stay concealed but fall apart badly if you prefer to kill quietly.  The shooting mechanics are hindered by poor controls - left trigger dives for cover instead of aiming down sights, etc - and by guns that just don't feel good.  It's great that the weapons can be upgraded in all manner of ways, but it's all for naught if they don't feel good to shoot.  Case in point: the round from a sniper rifle shouldn't drop in flight by 18 inches during a 25 yard shot.  Also, a guy that gets hit in the head with a finger-long projectile traveling at roughly 700 mph shouldn't immediately snap to attention and try to figure out who shot him just because he's wearing a helmet.  Finally, the parts of the game that attempt to challenge players by way of dialogue choices feels like LA Noire - the clues and responses that you're given don't correspond very tightly to the desired outcomes; two players making the same choices won't necessarily get the same result - it's stupid.All that said, the game features an intriguing story and is good enough (barely) at what it does to be worth playing.  The director's cut (poorly) incorporates the Missing Link DLC into the main campaign and adds some optional DVD-style commentary.  Unfortunately, because the upgrade exists as a separate title in the Steam library no saved games or achievements carry over into the new game.  I'd say that it's worth grabbing, but only if you don't already own The Missing Link.

content:
er 17, 2016
												This game was a love letter to the very first Deus Ex released way back in the year 2000 when The Matrix film was making waves in the science fiction community. HR follows almost the same plot as the first Deus Ex from the beginning, but thankfully HR has the benefit of modern gameplay.My favourite part of the game was using stealth to execute completely unnoticed "instant takedowns" (aka punching 1 or 2 dudes so hard that they were permanently knocked unconscious). The real challenge was hiding their sleeping bodies so that no other enemies would find and wake them.It was very easy to exploit this game's AI. I once lured 5 guards to the second floor just by running and jumping around. I laid them out unconscious side by side. You'd think they'd have radios for their commanding officer to check in! However, this is not a drawback. Rather, you can exploit the AI in many, many creative and funny ways, just like the first Deus Ex.Overall this game had the right balance of action, drama and humour. I recommend this game to anyone, not just Deus Ex fans.

ber 15, 2014
												Director's Cut is a big improvement on the original Deus Ex Human Revolution: better boss fights, developer commentary, the missing link dlc included, etc.I've played mostly the original version, so not the Director's Cut (that's why only 6 hours).- Perfect conspiracy storyline- Very satisfying gameplay- 3 ways to play: guns blazing, stealth assassin (lethal or non-lethal) or pacifist (avoid any combat by using cloaking, etc.)- Great visuals: graphics and art-style- Great music soundtracks and perfect voice acting overall- Rewards exploring within the open world city hubs and looking for alternative routes- Very smart leveling system to get praxis points that can be used to upgrade a wide variety of augmentations- Very satisfying hacking minigame that is also very useful against enemies and for resources- Bunch of side quests to find and also lots of npc to interact with- Wide variety of lethal and non-lethal weapons and gadgets for your weaponsI actually have no complains about it really.- Or no, there is 1 thing, the game could be even much better game if the developers had more time.Because during the developer commentary (turn it on or off in the option menu), the devs tell a lot about the stuff that was cut like sidequests, realtime translation augmentation, India city hub, etc.But overall, no complains. It is already a fantastic game without all the stuff that was cut from the game.And a great prequel for the original Deus Ex.I just love the art work in this game.10/10Worth buying for any price sale or not.One of the best singleplayer experiences, you'll have.

												I have never been so immersed into a video game before, and enjoyed every minute of playing Deus Ex.Deux Ex has the coolest and most interesting universe and plots of any game I have played, portraying a very believable and frightening future of a world in moral conflict and on the brink of civil war. The combat revolves around the player taking either a stealth approach or an aggresive one. Either way being fun, leaving players wanting to redo a checkpoint to perfect a certain method to complete it. This kind of gameplay has innevitably resulted in AI being a bit stuipid and too oblivious at times. Additionally, some boss fights are bit over the top and unnesccary.However, the variety of skills the player has to choose from and the unique environments of each chapter/level overshadows these faults.Deus Ex has been an example and of why games should be taken more seriously, and have alot more potential than being viewed as violent shoot em ups' as seen in the past.- 9/10

content:
r 27, 2014
												After a long break since the release of the original Deus Ex, we now have a new Deus Ex but not a sequel. Improved graphics, better game mechanics and a more involved story than the orignal. This is a very engrossing game but due to the limited nature of the storyline the re-playability of Deus Ex is limited. Having said all of that; this is probably one of the finest cyberpunk videogames ever made. With a nod to Gibson and Cyberpunk 2020, the world of Deus Ex captures the dark gritty dystopia of The Sprawl. Trust no one, take what you can get and forget about being a hero; this is the cyberpunk way. The combat system takes a little geting used to, but other than that and a few performance bugs this is a very fine game. I give it a 8/10, probably one of the highest ratings I have ever given a modern game.

If you are a newcommer to Human Revolution or your memory was a little shottier than mine you'd be forgiven for wondering which chapters in the game were the DLC. It works well.A work of unique art. 9/10

content:
r 30, 2014
												A rock solid game on many levels. It is one of the best stealth games that I have come across in the last few years. Yet, it's not just a stealth game. It provides several playstyles in which you can utilize during the game. The replayability factor simply rises because of it, as you naturally are tempted into playthroughs targetted to specific goals and playstyles.The graphics are solid, yet don't tax mid-range systems. Even some low end systems should be able to run with this title and still look decent. It's very easy on the eyes and the gpu at the same time. The story line is a cut above for it's genre, in my opinion. It has depth, color, imagination, and well-thought out twists and turns. When it's time to decide your stance in the world, you really feel like you're a part of this world. My advice is to not rush this game; don't view it as stages to be completed. Go everywhere, do everything... explore and take your time at each stage of the game... get lost in the character you're playing instead of the goal you're trying to achieve.This game doesn't fall short many places, but that's not saying it's perfect. There's room for expansion and improvement. I, for one, am really looking forward to any news of a sequel worthy of to succeed this game and see where they go with this amazing creation. I say one that is worthy of this game, because this game is quite literally the best entry into this franchise and the other titles that bear it's Dues Ex mark can't even stand in the same arena as this entry in my opinion.All in all, I give this game a 9/10 overall and highly recommend this game to anyone!

												Phew - finally done with the replay of DX. While it is fun to knock out people again, it is just the same game with a sharper / clearer image plus the Missing Link DLC added into it  - IMO I didn't really see much differences. Never have issues with the boss fights previously so I don't really see much even if it is changed a bit in this Director's Cut.Pros: *Above average storyline (provided you haven't played it before)*Good gameplay with either fun stealth features or average shooting/weapons to rush through it all*Good music (at least good enough for me to go download some of them =D)Cons:*Chat options doesn't affect the main storyline much (there are multiple endings but it is not really related to chat options)*Not much replay value (one run to do it all and I am removing this after 100%)*So-so AI (turning up the difficulty doesn't do much to me except increasing damage by guards and longer detection cooldown time)*A little bit repetitive on the hacking/sneaking if you are trying to max out on the experience Summary:While I might stated a few cons, it is still a good game that deserves your time if you haven't played/gotten it yet - especially after how cheap it is now. However if I can choose again, I probably won't be bothered to buy the Director's Cut, the plain vanilla + Missing Link DLC is more than sufficient. If you have not gotten any of the vanilla etc before, wait till Director's Cut get discounted and get it straight.

content:
er 29, 2016
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution (DXHR) is the third installment in the Deus Ex series of games. This is a prequel previous to both Deus Ex and Deus Ex: Invisible War.The previous games were set in the distant future (2050's) where human augmentation is a reality, the United States is no longer a major global power, mega corporations have filled the power vacuum and conspiracies underpin all of it.DXHR is however set some twenty years earlier in 2027. You portray Adam Jensen, chief of security of Sarif Industries, a mid-sized manufacturer of human augmentations and contractor to the United States military. Along with Megan Reed your former flame and chief scientist of the same company. Along with her and CEO David Sarif, they are about to make a major announcement of a discovery that will potentially make human augmentation accessible to all and not just those who can afford the drug Neuropozyne, which is required to prevent the body from rejecting the augmentation. With the goal to enhance human lives, David Sarif sees this as the start of the next stage of human evolution.This is the initial premise of the game as shown during the introduction/tutorial of the game. Like the previous installments it is a first person shooter with stealth elements and ability to complete tasks using different paths. Deus Ex was a personal favourite of mine when I played it because you could play the game largely as you liked (main plot missions withstanding) and then experience the consequences of your actions play out accordingly. In most respects DXHR features the same gameplay elements.There are three styles of play: direct approach, indirect approach and avoiding contact altogether. For instance to open a door you can take out a guard then take the code from them, hack a computer terminal for the code or just bypass the door itself.Combat likewise has varied options with melee combat (called a takedown), an array of short to long range ballistic, energy and chemical weapons as well as the option to (depending on the weapon of choice) lethally and non-lethally taking out your opponent. Almost all weapons can be upgraded to suit your style of play as well.This of course leads to the element of the game. Augmentations can be aquired as the game progresses and allows you to essentially gain superhuman abilities over time. I won't go into specifics as this is what makes Deus Ex stand out from other FPS's. But they are well worth the wait as they help you to complete tasks in a variety of new ways.Pro's:A lot of work and attention to detail went into the in-game environments and characters to create a credible immersive experience.Excellent writing and voice work by all involved. A lot of work went into getting everything right.Amazing soundtrack by Michael McCann. Fits and enhances the atmosphere and immersion in game immensely.The game strikes the right balance between being giving you many options in-game and the tasks themselves not being too generic as is the case in other FPS sand box style games.Con's:It felt like the developers were running out of time during production as the story speeds up significantly towards the end of the game.Diehard players with feel the game helps you too much in completing a task, some visual aids can be however turned off.The animations (especially during conversations) are repeatedly used which ruins some of the work gone into the characters themselves.Overall the game comprises a healthy mix of a well structured story, game play, character development all set in a cyberpunk, distopian future. If you feel this is up your alley I do recommend giving this game a go.

content:
ber 15, 2014
												Director's Cut is a big improvement on the original Deus Ex Human Revolution: better boss fights, developer commentary, the missing link dlc included, etc.I've played mostly the original version, so not the Director's Cut (that's why only 6 hours).- Perfect conspiracy storyline- Very satisfying gameplay- 3 ways to play: guns blazing, stealth assassin (lethal or non-lethal) or pacifist (avoid any combat by using cloaking, etc.)- Great visuals: graphics and art-style- Great music soundtracks and perfect voice acting overall- Rewards exploring within the open world city hubs and looking for alternative routes- Very smart leveling system to get praxis points that can be used to upgrade a wide variety of augmentations- Very satisfying hacking minigame that is also very useful against enemies and for resources- Bunch of side quests to find and also lots of npc to interact with- Wide variety of lethal and non-lethal weapons and gadgets for your weaponsI actually have no complains about it really.- Or no, there is 1 thing, the game could be even much better game if the developers had more time.Because during the developer commentary (turn it on or off in the option menu), the devs tell a lot about the stuff that was cut like sidequests, realtime translation augmentation, India city hub, etc.But overall, no complains. It is already a fantastic game without all the stuff that was cut from the game.And a great prequel for the original Deus Ex.I just love the art work in this game.10/10Worth buying for any price sale or not.One of the best singleplayer experiences, you'll have.

content:
er 17, 2016
												This game was a love letter to the very first Deus Ex released way back in the year 2000 when The Matrix film was making waves in the science fiction community. HR follows almost the same plot as the first Deus Ex from the beginning, but thankfully HR has the benefit of modern gameplay.My favourite part of the game was using stealth to execute completely unnoticed "instant takedowns" (aka punching 1 or 2 dudes so hard that they were permanently knocked unconscious). The real challenge was hiding their sleeping bodies so that no other enemies would find and wake them.It was very easy to exploit this game's AI. I once lured 5 guards to the second floor just by running and jumping around. I laid them out unconscious side by side. You'd think they'd have radios for their commanding officer to check in! However, this is not a drawback. Rather, you can exploit the AI in many, many creative and funny ways, just like the first Deus Ex.Overall this game had the right balance of action, drama and humour. I recommend this game to anyone, not just Deus Ex fans.

er 30, 2013
												Deus Ex follows on from both a Genre defining classic, and a disappointing cash-in kludge.Fortunately, though Human Revolution began by following in the footsteps of "Invisible War" with bugs and design mis-steps, notably having two levels of the game and some of the usable items ripped out to be game-store exclusives, and the entire bridghing third act yanked out to be a DLC... Not to mention the Boss Fight Thing.Human Revolution has grown up into a a sucessor to the original game: The missing levels and game section, complete with it's story and tools has been re-integrated, the graphics tweaked, bugs removed, and crucially for feel of it, you're now allowed to do more than run into a room screaming and shooting the boss characters in the face.As in the previous games, you get the chance to evade these situations and use alternate methods.Also included are Making Of and Commentary options and a new system to allow you to play through from the start with all your hard won upgrades.Sadly the Intel Intelliscreen system that was to allow you to use your phone or tablet as a controller seem to be nowhere to be found apart from as a commet that there is such a thing.

content:
er 26, 2013
												Still a great game.Lots of choice in how to approach situations, an interesting story and a very good non-lethal option.Graphically, it's distinctive, but texturing, both on characters and the environment, is spotty. While relatively high detail in most cases, it just feels a little amateurish sometimes. Character models also look a little odd, especially for characters that don't play a central part in the story.The orange/gold colour scheme can end up wearing you down too.I've never actually played the game focussing on weapons and combat, choosing the non-lethal route, so I can't comment on how gunplay feels, but stealth options are very satisfying.It is however a very long game, so doesn't lend itself to immediate replays. And this length is punishing if you're chasing achievements, particularly if you're going for one of the ones that relies on a perfect playthrough, such as Pacifist or Foxiest of the Hounds. There's no way of knowing you've failed these achievements until you've completed the game, and the systems can occasionally break beyond your control, potentially costing you the achievement.Still, the journey's a great one and the game deserves to be played

content:
9, 2016
												After owning it on the 360, and now on the PC, I have to say that this is a really good game. It's not only a decent game, but it is a great Deus Ex game. Especially considering the failure that was The Fall, and the controversial Invisible War, DEHR is a fantastic installment to the series.The graphics, the gameplay mechanics, the inventory, item construction and customization, the character upgrades, all of these are solid. Then we get into the story and dialogue. They are like nothing I have experienced before. Once you get the dialogue Praxis upgrade, it opens up a whole new gameplay feature, one that allows you to not only witness the effects of your choices during the dialogue sequence (not just after), but gives you a whole new way to play the game. It allows you to actually strategize during a conversation based on the individual person you're talking to and their personality, along with their emotional state at any given time, not just click one phrase and hope that the NPC has a favorable response to that particular selection.I am one of the few who actually like DE: Invisible War, but I have to admit that the inventory and (oh god) the dialogue and voice acting were bland and boring at best. Human Revolution doesn't fall victim to any of the failures of its older brother (and some would say a VERY distant relative). The voice acting is superb, the inventory is akin to The Conspiracy, item upgrades are more like the original, and the story and missions give you that sense of urgency that the original had.It's not just a good shooter, but it is a fantastic RPG. I've got to say that this is one (pre)sequel that I am proud to own and experience. Definitely recommended. A solid 9/10

												Highly addictive, if you are a fan of the first or Anachronox or into cyber punk themed worlds, this game won't dissapoint. Only negative side would be a few bugs that aren't addressed for this version that the original has already addressed through patches which is an awkward move by the developers, but based on the recent patch in november 2013 and a few posts on Eidos' forums, the technical team are listening to the fans in hopes of getting this game bug free. 												PROS:- Great atmosphere, full of interesting characters and intense social commentary.- Playing stealth and non-lethal is rewarding, adds additional challenge to an otherwise standard FPS game.- New Game+ allows for repeat playthroughs with all of your previous upgrades allowing for different outcomes.CONS:- Random stuttering near tight areas and walls, even at high settings. It’s annoying, but bearable.- Boss fights can be laughably easy near the end, offering little challenge.- Heavy backtracking is required for several Side Missions, making the world feel grindy.Fans of the action-stealth genre will find plenty to enjoy in Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut. The boss fights have been reworked to include alternative ways to win. New Game+ can extend the life of the game for additional replayability. Other than some graphical hitches, buying this game on sale is one of the best value you can get.

												Played the original version back in 2011 and loved it! One of the best games I played of last generation and a worthy follow up to the masterpiece that is Deus Ex!A really engaging story which had me interested from the get go, some really well designed environments that let you choose which approach you take to complete objectives. 												A fantastic Cyberpunk RPG. While your actions in a given quest don't have the biggest impact on the overall story, the freedom and possible resolutions available within any given quest is pretty impressive. content:
r 27, 2014
												After a long break since the release of the original Deus Ex, we now have a new Deus Ex but not a sequel. Improved graphics, better game mechanics and a more involved story than the orignal. This is a very engrossing game but due to the limited nature of the storyline the re-playability of Deus Ex is limited. Having said all of that; this is probably one of the finest cyberpunk videogames ever made. With a nod to Gibson and Cyberpunk 2020, the world of Deus Ex captures the dark gritty dystopia of The Sprawl. Trust no one, take what you can get and forget about being a hero; this is the cyberpunk way. The combat system takes a little geting used to, but other than that and a few performance bugs this is a very fine game. I give it a 8/10, probably one of the highest ratings I have ever given a modern game.

content:
r 30, 2014
												A rock solid game on many levels. It is one of the best stealth games that I have come across in the last few years. Yet, it's not just a stealth game. It provides several playstyles in which you can utilize during the game. The replayability factor simply rises because of it, as you naturally are tempted into playthroughs targetted to specific goals and playstyles.The graphics are solid, yet don't tax mid-range systems. Even some low end systems should be able to run with this title and still look decent. It's very easy on the eyes and the gpu at the same time. The story line is a cut above for it's genre, in my opinion. It has depth, color, imagination, and well-thought out twists and turns. When it's time to decide your stance in the world, you really feel like you're a part of this world. My advice is to not rush this game; don't view it as stages to be completed. Go everywhere, do everything... explore and take your time at each stage of the game... get lost in the character you're playing instead of the goal you're trying to achieve.This game doesn't fall short many places, but that's not saying it's perfect. There's room for expansion and improvement. I, for one, am really looking forward to any news of a sequel worthy of to succeed this game and see where they go with this amazing creation. I say one that is worthy of this game, because this game is quite literally the best entry into this franchise and the other titles that bear it's Dues Ex mark can't even stand in the same arena as this entry in my opinion.All in all, I give this game a 9/10 overall and highly recommend this game to anyone!

content:
9, 2014
												The original release was one of the best games of 2011, hands down. It has a deep, rich storyline and setting that fans of cyberpunk--from Blade Runner to Ghost in the Shell--will greatly appreciate. The gameplay is smooth and challenging, and players of games such as Metal Gear Solid, Mass Effect, Thief, and the original Deus Ex will find themselves right at home with this fantastic title.With the Director's Cut, a few changes and additions have been made. The most notable of these are the inclusion of the DLC missions into the main campaign--the Missing Link is no longer a separate game--the improved boss fights, and the developer commentary. There were other minor changes, but many players may not notice these. The inclusion of the Missing Link chapter helps round out the storyline, as well as give the player the opportunity to redo his or her skill points, which was something missing from the original 2011 release.The improved boss fights were appreciated, though the additional avenues of defeating the bosses will still take some quick thinking, or trial and error, to truly take advantage. For fans that want a more balanced approach to the game, where any style of play is rewarded, this is the edition to purchase.Developer commentary in this version of the game is an interesting and valuable addition. It can be toggled on or off at the player's convenience, and many of the nodes offer intriguing insight into the minds of the game's creators. The only minor irritations with the commentary involve the nodes themselves. They are not always apparent in the game world, and once a node is playing it cannot be stopped without going into the main menu options and toggling the commentary off. Still, in spite of that minor oversight, the commentary is exciting to listen to and veteran players will appreciate it.I highly recommend that new and old fans of Deus Ex: Human Revolution grab a copy of the Director's Cut.

content:
, 2014
DISCLAIMER: Don't get fooled by many negative reviews, most of them compare Director's Cut to the original. Original, however, doesn't seem to be available on Steam anymore, so if you've never played it, this is your best (and only) chance!Now, let's get on with the review.Never played Human Revolution? - Get it!Already played HR, should I get Director's Cut? - Got money to spare? Want trading cards/badges? Missed DLC? Sure, go for it. Otherwise, not really. Pros- amazing story- dialogue and other choices have effects later on- you can choose stealth and not kill a single enemy or go on an all-out killing spree. You can also combine those two approaches- multiple solutions to various situations- custom select your abilities (augmentations) to fit your playstyle- a lot of playtime for purely single-player experience (first playthrough is likely going to take you 20-30 hours, how many single-player games offer that nowadays?)Cons- a lot of moving between objectives and your sprinting doesn't last all that long(Wow, that's all I could come up with. I may add some more later but right now, I can't seem to think of anything else that could bother someone. Note: See the Differences section below for potential cons)Differences between regular and Director's Cut [+/-]+ re-worked bossfights, making them less harsh on players who choose stealth + integrated DLC- colors seem washed out, can be fixed with ENB- may encounter some performance issues and/or bugs. Personally, I didn't notice any but maybe I'm just lucky.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
14, 2014
												Oh, where to begin?  Deux Ex is a decent game, blending concepts of stealth, shooting, and social engineering.  Unfortunately, it doesn't really excel in any area.  The stealth sequences are very old-fashioned, in that they work well enough if you choose to stay concealed but fall apart badly if you prefer to kill quietly.  The shooting mechanics are hindered by poor controls - left trigger dives for cover instead of aiming down sights, etc - and by guns that just don't feel good.  It's great that the weapons can be upgraded in all manner of ways, but it's all for naught if they don't feel good to shoot.  Case in point: the round from a sniper rifle shouldn't drop in flight by 18 inches during a 25 yard shot.  Also, a guy that gets hit in the head with a finger-long projectile traveling at roughly 700 mph shouldn't immediately snap to attention and try to figure out who shot him just because he's wearing a helmet.  Finally, the parts of the game that attempt to challenge players by way of dialogue choices feels like LA Noire - the clues and responses that you're given don't correspond very tightly to the desired outcomes; two players making the same choices won't necessarily get the same result - it's stupid.All that said, the game features an intriguing story and is good enough (barely) at what it does to be worth playing.  The director's cut (poorly) incorporates the Missing Link DLC into the main campaign and adds some optional DVD-style commentary.  Unfortunately, because the upgrade exists as a separate title in the Steam library no saved games or achievements carry over into the new game.  I'd say that it's worth grabbing, but only if you don't already own The Missing Link.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 16, 2016
												Stealth games have lately sucked, mainly for the simple reason that you’re too damn strong and the game keeps telling you that killing them is wrong when they would do it right away if they had a chance. It makes games such as Dishonored kinda suck as I personally don’t even feel like playing on a stealthy way when you can just kill them on one hit and they’ll take minutes and dozens of men to do the same thing to you. That’s different on Deus Ex. I wasn’t the biggest fan of the first game as it was overly confusing and too complex when I first got it over 10 years ago, I was young and I couldn’t get a liking to it… But when I grew up, I played the living f#ck of it. So sure I would get this game. I got the normal one, I got the DLC, and I even got the Director’s Cut Edition. Is it worth it? As usual I’m gonna start by what it does wrong.First and foremost, the animations. I’m not sure why, but I just can’t get a liking to most NPC’s animations. They look stiff and really forced, specially at the start of the game. Hostile NPC’s do look believable, but friendly NPC’s keep acting like robots, lots of them even reusing the same animations like you wouldn’t notice.Something I also found somewhat annoying are the boss fights. Now hear me here, they were A BILLION TIMES WORSE BEFORE. On the original game, you had to fight bosses on a lethal way, no matter if you’re playing on a stealthy hacking way or guns blazing, it was a big gameplay flaw that could seriously ruin stealth runs. It was somewhat fixed on the Director’s Cut by giving a few different options such as using turrets to do it for you, but it’s still weak. It could have been way better.Another thing I didn’t like were the endings. On a game this damn long, around 20 hours of good story and gameplay, WHILE IN THE ACTUAL #NAL F#CK SH#T DO ALL ENDINGS JUST TURN INTO STOCK FOOTAGE WITH A VOICE-OVER!? It’s the laziest sh#t ever! It TRULY feels like you’ve accomplished NOTHING. Lastly, the hacking minigame is a bit too random at times. You start it to get a door open, suddenly it starts flashing red colors on a 25% detection checkpoint and you’re WAAAAY too far away to get there in time. If you go into a stealth run and are forced to hack stuff, you better stock on viruses. You’ll need them if you’re unlucky.Taking the trash out however, we do find quite a few gems on the game.Where the game shines the most is the gameplay. Remember the comparison to other stealth games such as Dishonored? Here you truly can do it however you feel like, and it TRULY feels like it makes a difference. In Dishonored it barely changes the last levels and gives you a different ending cinematic, while here taking the brutal guns-blazing option from the start makes others question if what you’re doing is right.I also like how weapons work. Lethal or non-lethal, you can upgrade them throughout the game and turn a sh#tty generic pistol into a death-sentence that has a silencer, can work through armor like it’s warm butter and has 25 bullet magazines. At the same time though, the game never gives you too much ammo of one thing, usually only giving you two or three bullets out of enemies you’ve taken out, making you actually take aim and be careful on whatever the hell you’re doing with your fancy toys. That also somewhat expands to augmentations. Throughout the game you’ll get Praxis thingies that can be used to make your character better in a good variety of ways. Want to be invisible for short durations of time? Want to see through walls? Want to jump higher? Want to be immune to fall damage? Want to have a better aim when shooting? Want to make less to no noise when walking or running? Want to pick up a fridge and shove it up someone’s #ss? It’s all there, and you choose what to do.The voice-acting and music department is actually quite a big point on this game. Everyone sounds real, truly immersed on their role on the big story the game has. Specially the main character who, although a bit clichéd and being a bit parody to Robocop, is likable and quite a badass.The game also offers a good variety of ways to get to the desired objective… Except with bosses as I’ve already said. Even on Stealth runs, there’s usually multiple ways to get there, it’s all up to you to find them.Also, the game shows some Dev foresight as they got NPC’s ready to react to things you might have not expect to. You steal everything from the building you’re working at as security chief? People will send you emails complaining about multiple thefts happening. People give you a quest about taking out drug lords you’ve already executed and dunked their face to the ground? They’ll call you out on it. These kinds of things are quite unexpected and funny as hell.Do I recommend this game? Yeah! It’s a really good experience which truly gives you freedom to do whatever you feel like. It has a good length, the DLC’s already added to the game and it’s a fun experience. The bosses suck, but that’s a low price against a good amount of great content. You might have never asked for this, but you should give it a try.TL;DR Edition: A good example of a stealth game. Boss fights kinda still suck, but offers tons of variety on a quite long experience. Would totally recommend on a sale. IT TRULY IS A BOMB!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
15, 2015
												How did you get this frequency? You want a review? I never asked for this, but here we go.Short version: It will be worth the money, more so during sales.Long(er) version:Deus EX: Human Revolution is an enjoyable and compelling game with an interesting story and decent gameplay. There is content for quite a while and situations can be approached in different ways.Condensed list of the good and the bad, mostly arranged by personal experience:The game is enjoyable, but has some noticable flaws in the gameplay.Movement is the major offender with limited sprint, poor strafing capabilities, fiddly jumping mechanic and needlessly prompted actions (such as moving from cover to cover, around a cover and climbing) accompanied by awkward cutscenes (Icarus Landing System).Combat is enjoyable and as stated earlier, the multiple approaches available offer a commendable value to the gameplay. Direct, long range and hidden assaults are all viable options with each having a lethal and non-lethal variety. One downside in Deus Ex: HR's combat is the melee system. Unlike the previous game(s), HR does not have melee weapons that can be equipped like other equipment, but instead you are given prompts every time you are near an enemy. This activates a cutscene where you use your arms to knock the target(s) unconscious or kill them.Activating the prompt uses an energy cell, which limits the melee use further.Gunplay is one of the few things that feel just spot on with variety of large and small weapons, each offering their own characteristics.[Edit] There are also minor bugs to be expected.In comparison to the first game in the franchise (Deus Ex), the freedom of movement is much more limited. Certain cutscenes, Icarus Landing System for example tug you right out of the game. The greatest strengths of Deus Ex: HR are its story and dialogue in addition to combat and gunplay.HR could be described as a good B-movie; an enjoyable experience with its own flaws.

content:
, 2014
												First, some reviewers on here did not recommend this title because they claimed it was buggy. I did not experience a single bug from my 30 hour playthrough so I am not quite sure as to what they were referring to. As far as the DLC that comes with this title: the DLC mission is integrated so seamlessly into the main story that I didn't even realize it was the DLC until after I had completed the game. I think the best part about Deus Ex: Human Revolution is it literally allows you to play the game however you wish. Do you enjoy complete stealth missions and sneaking around? You can do that and there are weapons designed specifically for stealth (tranquilizers and stun guns for example). Do you enjoy running in and blowing up everyone you see with a rocket launcher? You can do that too. You have special augmentations that you choose to unlock in order to play the game to your style. For example you can unlock short bursts of invisibility in order to avoid being seen; or if you choose to fight you can augment hand to hand combat and weapon abilities. The game is designed so that you, the player, are given the ability to choose exactly how you play the game.As far as the story goes, it was good/above average but not amazing. It felt extremely rabbit holey. The rabbit hole went down so far that I just kept thinking to myself "welp, I guess I'll find the bottom around 50 hours in." The story has a lot of twists and turns, but none of them are particularly interesting. It was just like, ok, you found out something new, better go check it out.. and down the rabbit hole you go. Rinse and repeat. But it was never an overly interesting rabbit hole. On the flipside, the ending is simply one of the best endings I have experienced. It reminds you of just how empowering, yet brutally dangerous technology can be to society. To quote Einstein: "Technological progress is like an axe in the hands of a pathological criminal."Overall, the gameplay is one of the best I've experienced. The story mixes technology and the choices it forces on human morality. This title is close to perfection in both terms of gameplay and story, and I can't give the developers enough praise. Deus Ex: Human Revolution takes about 20 hours playtime to finish, and about 30 hours if you do all the side missions. 9.5/10Please upvote this review if you found it useful :)

												I have never been so immersed into a video game before, and enjoyed every minute of playing Deus Ex.Deux Ex has the coolest and most interesting universe and plots of any game I have played, portraying a very believable and frightening future of a world in moral conflict and on the brink of civil war. The combat revolves around the player taking either a stealth approach or an aggresive one. Either way being fun, leaving players wanting to redo a checkpoint to perfect a certain method to complete it. This kind of gameplay has innevitably resulted in AI being a bit stuipid and too oblivious at times. Additionally, some boss fights are bit over the top and unnesccary.However, the variety of skills the player has to choose from and the unique environments of each chapter/level overshadows these faults.Deus Ex has been an example and of why games should be taken more seriously, and have alot more potential than being viewed as violent shoot em ups' as seen in the past.- 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												The original release was one of the best games of 2011, hands down. It has a deep, rich storyline and setting that fans of cyberpunk--from Blade Runner to Ghost in the Shell--will greatly appreciate. The gameplay is smooth and challenging, and players of games such as Metal Gear Solid, Mass Effect, Thief, and the original Deus Ex will find themselves right at home with this fantastic title.With the Director's Cut, a few changes and additions have been made. The most notable of these are the inclusion of the DLC missions into the main campaign--the Missing Link is no longer a separate game--the improved boss fights, and the developer commentary. There were other minor changes, but many players may not notice these. The inclusion of the Missing Link chapter helps round out the storyline, as well as give the player the opportunity to redo his or her skill points, which was something missing from the original 2011 release.The improved boss fights were appreciated, though the additional avenues of defeating the bosses will still take some quick thinking, or trial and error, to truly take advantage. For fans that want a more balanced approach to the game, where any style of play is rewarded, this is the edition to purchase.Developer commentary in this version of the game is an interesting and valuable addition. It can be toggled on or off at the player's convenience, and many of the nodes offer intriguing insight into the minds of the game's creators. The only minor irritations with the commentary involve the nodes themselves. They are not always apparent in the game world, and once a node is playing it cannot be stopped without going into the main menu options and toggling the commentary off. Still, in spite of that minor oversight, the commentary is exciting to listen to and veteran players will appreciate it.I highly recommend that new and old fans of Deus Ex: Human Revolution grab a copy of the Director's Cut.

content:
, 2014
												More than fun, this game is meaningful. It really asks questions about society, humankind, morality, and on what might happen if we stray too far from humanity. This game really stands out. In regards to playthrough, this game is loaded with interesting material. The story is great, the characters are interesting (Jensen himself is such a fun character to play), and the options are limitless. The game really allows you to choose how you want to play, whether that be through charging ranks, sneaking around and avoiding detection, or even choosing to tranquilize enemies instead of kill them. Each location is challenging and rewarding, but also downright fun. Truly the best part about this game is the stimulating and beautiful environment, and the idea of augmentations and how they help and hinder society. This is a game everyone should experience. It will remain in your memory for a long time.

content:
2016
												If you are wondering whether to buy this game or not, just do it. I can assure you that you won't be disappointed.And if you decide to buy it then keep playing it until you finish it. The first 2 hours of the game aren't that interesting, but it gets so much better. The reason why i like it so much is because you choose how you want to play. You can play lethal guns blazing or maybe some nonlethal stealth, maybe you want to play the whole game without hurting anyone. (With the exception of the bosses.) The choice is yours. The choices you make isn't just limited to the type of playstyle you have but also what you choose to say in the dialogue sections. Speaking of which, the moral choices you make are really tough decisions and they definetly have an impact on the storyline. I found myself thinking about what to do a lot, and I kept doing that until the end. I didn't know if I made the right decisions. Not many games will make me question my outlook on life and my morals, but this game opened my eyes to problems that might actually happen in the future. That is really cool.It does have it's problems though, for example; The boss fights are boring and unnecessary, the guns are a bit clunky (Barely used guns anyway but still), the lack of a fast travel system made side quests a bit of a chore (Even though the actual side quests where really interesting) and I personally didn't enjoy the the first couple hours of the game.I would rate this game: I never asked fo this/10Keep in my mind that these are my personal opinions and nobody else's.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
12, 2016
												Much like the humans in this world who augment their bodies and minds to gain an upper hand in society, Deus Ex: Human Revolution aspires to be greater than other videogames on the market, and it succeeds impeccably. You are Adam Jensen an augmented cyber security agent for the world’s leading augmented research corporation Sarif Industries. Your goal is to solve who is behind a serious of terror attacks on the company by any means necessary. However, just because you are given the tools of the gods does not mean you should necessarily utilize them. Deus Ex is a game about choice and unlike other games that advertise choice as a key aspect of the game and fail to deliver Deus Ex delivers it, and with a cyber fueled bang! You influence the story and you decide your play style whether it involves becoming a sneaky hacker or a near indestructible cyber death machine, there is no hand holding or hints of what the game wants you to do, make your choices and live with your consequences. Whether that means changing the course of a characters path into an ill-fated direction or not properly preparing for a mission and getting destroyed by your opponents it’s all up to you. The story takes an immense amount of shocking turns as it stacks the stakes with every second you play the game resulting in an ending where based on your perceptions of the world you decide what the best course of action for its survival, and boy is this world something. Resembling the light on shadow styles of renaissance paintings Deus Ex strongly resembles a crumbling Sci-fi dystopia somewhere along the lines of Blade Runner or Dredd with a mesmerizing soundtrack and a hypnotizing environment. Deus Ex: Human Revolution is truly fire stolen straight from the gods.

content:
2, 2014
												I bought this game just because it looked kinda cool.  Honestly, this game has its flaws, I won't deny it, the boss battles are ♥♥♥♥, the story has some parts that don't make much sense, and the ending was lackluster.  However, I haven't had this much fun playing a single-player since ♥♥♥♥ing Half Life 2.  The Metascore is not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t for once, it actually deserves its 91/100.The stealth gameplay is superb, the cover-based shooting is really fun, the AI is relatively smart, and the augmentations really add different ways to play the game, which adds a lot of replayability.  For example, if you want to play it very stealthily, you can spend your praxis points on invisibility, computer hacking, and silent footsteps.  Or, if you want to go in guns blazing, you can buy dermal armor, aim stabilizer, and the Typhoon Explosive System.To sum up, I absolutely did not expect this game to be this fun to play.  Don't get me wrong, it has its flaws, however, the gameplay and augmentations are so amazing, that they completely negate the flaws.  I spent my entire Thanksgiving vacation with my ♥♥♥ glued to my office chair playing this game.  This is my #1 favorite game of all time because I love stealth games, and there are none better in my opinion.Edit:  I played the original Deus Ex after playing this, and I think that this is a worthy sequal.  They original has a longer and deeper story, but the gampley is old.  Also, the two hub worlds of Detroit and Hengsha are filled with fun side missions which aren't necessary for the main story, but can add to it or sometimes privide further explanations of parts of the story.  Because I value gameplay above story, I like this game slightly more than the original.

content:
er 27, 2013
												This is a worthy successor to the original Deus Ex game. In my opinion it is not as good as the original. But it certainly comes very close.It certainly feels like a true Deus Ex game. While it has a mostly linear story, you get lots of freedom moving around in hub areas and how you take on different missions. There are always more ways to get around a certain problem. You can go guns blazing into a firefight. You can be silent as the night and sneak by guards without killing a single soul.The graphic style is very appealing. The story and voice acting are great and the combat is solid.On the downside though, the game has a few problems. Chief among these are the boss fights. Though the Director's Cut does feature improved boss fights. They are still not as strong as the rest of the game and there is no way around them. When compared to the original Deus Ex, there are also a few things that could have been done more elegantly. The way the experience works kinda works against exploring different solutions to certain problems. For example: Hacking a terminal will always give you more experience than finding the code for the same terminal. There is also little difference between nonlethal and lethal takedowns. With an arbitrairy push of a button you can choose between life and death without much difference in consequence. There are also times when the level design feels a little gamey and could have been a little more elegant (though I am nitpicking here).The Director's Cut is definitely worth it compared to the normal version of Deus Ex: Human Revolution.As I mentioned earlier the bossfights have been improved. There is now much more freedom in how the bosses are defeated. So you won't find yourself being underpowered because you chose a certain build.All the original DLC is now also fully integrated into the game by default. The DLC was worth it to begin with. But this change just makes the whole thing just a little more smooth. There were a number of bugs before, but as far as I know most of these have been ironed out by now.To conclude, if you like Cyberpunk and are looking for a shooter RPG that provides lots of freedom in play styles. I wholeheartedly recommend this games. Because dispite some minor flaws, it really is a fantastic game and I enjoyed it immensly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 9, 2014
												One of the most interesting games in recent years. Deus Ex: HR thrusts you into an immersive, highly detailed and interactive, deeply conflicted, and plausible future world that asks many questions about where technology will lead us, but doesn't give clear cut answers. Not only is it thought provoking, but the blend of stealth action and role-playing is second to none. Choices matter and you'll often find yourself in really intense scenarios, for which the outcome is ultimately decided by the player.This game thankfully avoids many game design pitfalls, and really shines because of it.  The plot is elievable the whole way and doesn't push your suspension of disbelief too much, which is rare for games... and movies and TV shows too.  The character development is noteworthy, the story is quite easy to relate to I find.  The stealth gameplay is a bit more rewarding and enjoyable than combat, but the player can choose either one or both whenever they feel like it.  It has much bigger, more content heavy hubs than the original, and overall far more detailed level design.  It has a bit less "choice and consequence" than the original though, along with a more serious and mature tonality.

content:
y 31, 2014
												Ah... Deus Ex.I got this game as a gift from my brother, since I bought him a few games as well. It took a while to download (as you'd imagine, 15 GB is a very large game) and I never really got around to playing it. I got bored from WoW and so I decided to play this game.This game's setting is in 2027 in North America. You are an ex-SWAT member who is a guard at Sarif Industries, where a revolutionary new find equal to that of the Rosetta Stone or Kepler's find is being worked on -- the find of controlled human evolution. This is being made available only to the high-ranked citizens of America (while you hate this find in general, you despise the fact that it is not available to all). This game feels very Mass Effect-y (my favorite game all time), with everything from the music to controlled dialogue to the futuristic aspect. While you are speaking to "your boss", something happens in the labs. I'm not going to say what, because a) I just started playing, and b) I wouldn't wanna spoil it for you all.This game, from what I've discovered, can be played from a stealth perspective or a full frontal perspective. There are missions and level-ups, where you can improve your character's body. (One thing that I dislike is that you can't modify how you look.) A great thing about this game is that when you hear what's going on you feel as if you're on the wrong side -- however, there isn't much you can do. This can make you hate everyone (as I do right now) and yet make you feel so right. I don't know how to explain it, all I can say is that this is quite a fantastic game and if you liked Mass Effect then you'll like this game too. Get this game, it's one of the best games in my library and I have games like Torchlight II and Skyrim in there ;)10/10

content:
ry 9, 2014
												Very great game, this was the first Deus Ex game I have played, and so I have started playing the others. Although I have noticed how "easy" this game is compared to the others... but that can dealt with by going through the settings and disabling a few things here and there. It definitely has a great storyline and it is amazing compared to other video games I have played. They have created this universe so realistically well that it actually feel it could happen. In the DIrector's Cut edition of the game, it adds in The Missing Link DLC and another DLC-thingy with weapons and such. The Missing Link suprisingly was implemented well into the game, and I loved it. It delved farther into the discovery of the conspiracy behind the "Tyrants" and such. And, the art style for this game is truly magnificient. It has that "cyberpunk noire" with the gleaming yellow lights and the triangularly-shaped objects most commonly seen give off a deep sense of some sort of movement, or revolution as you will, from modern times into a new future. I was a bit dissapointed in the Director's Cut when they lowered down the yellowness in the game. But it sorta balanced out my mood with the added in weapons. This game has made me move on to read the book Deus Ex: Icarus Effect and also play Deus Ex 1! Very amazing game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 9, 2014
												One of the most interesting games in recent years. Deus Ex: HR thrusts you into an immersive, highly detailed and interactive, deeply conflicted, and plausible future world that asks many questions about where technology will lead us, but doesn't give clear cut answers. Not only is it thought provoking, but the blend of stealth action and role-playing is second to none. Choices matter and you'll often find yourself in really intense scenarios, for which the outcome is ultimately decided by the player.This game thankfully avoids many game design pitfalls, and really shines because of it.  The plot is elievable the whole way and doesn't push your suspension of disbelief too much, which is rare for games... and movies and TV shows too.  The character development is noteworthy, the story is quite easy to relate to I find.  The stealth gameplay is a bit more rewarding and enjoyable than combat, but the player can choose either one or both whenever they feel like it.  It has much bigger, more content heavy hubs than the original, and overall far more detailed level design.  It has a bit less "choice and consequence" than the original though, along with a more serious and mature tonality.

content:
3, 2014
												Haven't played a game this great in a while. Although some of the missions can be very difficult even at the medium difficulty, I still find the missions fun, and IMO this game gets the best of both worlds from the shooter genre and the RPG genre. The soundtrack is pretty good, too, and the story is even better.That being said, I do feel like this game lacks in the shooter part just a bit. One of the first things I noticed in the gunfights was how unnatural ADS felt. I also think the switching from first person to third person when taking cover could be a lot more smooth. Still, these complaints are very minor.9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 31, 2014
												Ah... Deus Ex.I got this game as a gift from my brother, since I bought him a few games as well. It took a while to download (as you'd imagine, 15 GB is a very large game) and I never really got around to playing it. I got bored from WoW and so I decided to play this game.This game's setting is in 2027 in North America. You are an ex-SWAT member who is a guard at Sarif Industries, where a revolutionary new find equal to that of the Rosetta Stone or Kepler's find is being worked on -- the find of controlled human evolution. This is being made available only to the high-ranked citizens of America (while you hate this find in general, you despise the fact that it is not available to all). This game feels very Mass Effect-y (my favorite game all time), with everything from the music to controlled dialogue to the futuristic aspect. While you are speaking to "your boss", something happens in the labs. I'm not going to say what, because a) I just started playing, and b) I wouldn't wanna spoil it for you all.This game, from what I've discovered, can be played from a stealth perspective or a full frontal perspective. There are missions and level-ups, where you can improve your character's body. (One thing that I dislike is that you can't modify how you look.) A great thing about this game is that when you hear what's going on you feel as if you're on the wrong side -- however, there isn't much you can do. This can make you hate everyone (as I do right now) and yet make you feel so right. I don't know how to explain it, all I can say is that this is quite a fantastic game and if you liked Mass Effect then you'll like this game too. Get this game, it's one of the best games in my library and I have games like Torchlight II and Skyrim in there ;)10/10

content:
er 28, 2015
												I consider Deus Ex: Human Revolution a decent game with some very strong pros but also some alarming cons. Overall I recommend this game because it brings something on the table that's unique and well executed. However, I can't say that I was left completely satisfied or that my positive emotions skyrocketed through the roof.Pros:+ Idea of the so called 'augmentations' highly original.+ Different paths to complete the missions.+ Wonderful stealth takedown.+ Nice character build.+ Memorable protagonist.+ Useful weapons and nice weapon upgrades.+ Cool little hacking minigame.+ Getting shot gets you killed FAST.Cons:- The environment is a maze which really brings down the game tempo. On top of that there's a lot of backtracking which replaces the fun of sneaking past guards with frustration. I found myself over and over again getting impatient about how the game artificially tried to slow me down. - Not the most helpful minimap.- Not that great of a level design.- Poor inventory.- Black and white backstory with a very predictable plot. - Badly written readable material and poor dialogues.- Frustrating boss battles in small contained areas (cage-battles basically).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
23, 2016
												Buckle up because this is my favourite game of all time.Barring World of Warcraft, Vanilla, which must take the top title on account of the ungodly number of days I spent playing the thing, I have never enjoyed a gaming experience as totally as I did with this game.You must know that this was an important game for me because it accessed my interests in a way that few games in the past five or six years had managed to. Prior to DE:HR I am quite sure I had not completed a narrative-driven game for half a decade. Many great titles had come and gone but none of them had gotten through to me, distracted as I was by University studies, to such an extent that I was motivated to put in the time to complete them.Deus Ex: HR held no such difficulties.Maybe it was the formula, the open ended nature of the levels, perhaps the story. Maybe it was the challenge, certainly a huge part had to do with the stylish presentation - everything from the menu and HUD design to the soundtrack and of course the graphics oozed classy cyberpunk immersion.Really though, it was simply everything. I have never played through this game on any difficult level less than the maximum setting, and I have never played it as a run-and-gun shooter. I urge you to follow suit, because the stealth controls for this title are fantastic. Beyond simple stealth movement, consider the natural extension of that - exploration. The idea of multiple routes to an objective has been adopted in this game to such an extent - in almost all cases - that linearity has departed completely. Even the famous bugaboos of the original build of the game didn't bother me. The boss fights that forced you to engage in combat didn't phase me one iota: here I was, someone who had basically completed entire zones without killing a soul, reloading save after save, refining my game plan and whittling down the boss with horrendously unskilled weapon talents. Quicksaving every time I ran across open ground, got a few rounds into the hulking fellow and found cover again without going splat!. I may be a bit oldfashioned in the way I cosider this kind of difficulty appealing - indeed, I often say that I very much preferred Vanilla WoW to later iterations precisely because it took whole weeks of your life to net anything worthwhile - and those of you reading this review will be pleased to know that the Director's Cut edition no longer contains these bottleneck boss fights - they now all feature multiple routes towards completion, as with the rest of the content. (the boss fights had been outsourced to a separate company who had failed to grasp what DE was all about)The attention to detail, atmosphere, challenge, great variation in gameplay and excellent replayability all go in to making Deus Ex: HR my favourite FPS, favourite RPG, and pretty much my favourite game period, of all time.The downsides are few and far between. Somewhat like the GTA and Elder Scrolls games one finds oneself wishing the non-questgiving NPCs walking around town could contribute even vaguely to the atmosphere the rest of the game has so carefully constructed, and an act set in a futuristic Chinese city has a vaguely disappointing resolution (at least part of that dissapointment comes simply from the fact that the zone ends and you must stop exploring it) The graphics have aged slightly - the character models for one are really previous-gen by now. One would expect bump mapping, skin pores - the kinda things you marveled at on the face of Prophet in Crysis - but instead the faces are dissapointingly smooth, as if cut from clay. That said, and this is applicable to all of the qualms one might have about this game, there is another side: The facial graphics might be a bit tedious by now, but on the same coin the combat, movement, environmental and explosion graphics among many others are all fantastic.Play this game, if you have any respect at all for your human right to enjoy the art of computer gaming then play this game on max difficulty and try to avoid the run-and-gun approach if it is at all possible. That is all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2015
												Rating: 8/10Replayability: LowBudget: Fairly old game by now, still pricy due to quality - Worth it. Length: Takes a few days to beat. Pros: Great story, decent engine, good graphics (even by today's standards, the game is decent enough to play), the game has a sequel coming up soon, choices and consequences - The game actively makes you reap what you sow, great dialogue system on par with other RPGs from that time, and even some today - fully voice acted, great story. Cons: Human Revolution is optimized for console, which can seem like a big minus, unless you own a controller for your PC, which seriously smoothens the experience. Somewhat confusing inventory system. Very harsh gameplay where you get severely punished for missing minor details early in the game. Very confusing endings (to the point where beating the game actually seems pointless compared to simply playing it). Whether you're new to the Deus Ex series, or this is your first attempt, this game is a good place to start. The older games certainly hold good memories for those who played them when they came out, but due to possitively ancient gameplay - many people simply will not consider them playable anymore. Story-wise, there doesn't seem to be anything you explicitly have to know from the previous games, in order to enjoy Human Revolution, so it's not really a sequel, but just another game in the series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2015
												Great game. Things I Like > > Things I Don't Like. I tend to be reminded of a game called Splinter Cell. If you could combine Spinter Cell, Deus Ex : Human Revolution, Dishonored, WarFrame, Hitman etc... You could make a very difficult stealth game that requires you to utilize all your superhuman powers to complete the stage. Crawling or duck-walking everywhere is very funny. It's an amazing story and game. $8.98 SGDPROS1. Multi-choiceThere are many ways to play this game. Stealth, Combat, Exploration. Stealth and Combat are self-explainatory but Exploration is something different. E.g. You can get a Hive Membership that allows you to enter a night club (The Hive) as a member instead of sneaking around or shooting everyone up.2. Non-Playable CharactersSemi-interesting. The NPCs respond to you and give you useful information, most of them don't function as "lamp posts". While asking them repeatedly still gets a botted response, it is more interesting compared to other games. It is still far off from an interesting character.3. Wall Hack Vision (F3)Very cool. Very useful.4. HackingFun to hack everything. From doors, safes, security locks and computers. The mini-game isn't so fun though. It's basically "Find-the-shortest-route-to-the-green-balls". You can't hack cameras or turrets directly, only through their control station. You need an upgrade to turn them on their enemies though.5. Tranquilizer GunBeing able to use a non-lethal form of taking out an opponent is most fun. It's difficult to shoot through bars but doable.6. Box bots / Guard RobotsIt's a big giant mecha-walker. Very cool. I thought they would incorporate more of these things. I'm not sure if you can hack into them, yet.7. CASIEDating Sim Simulator. Funny and useful. Going to unlock it soon.8. Boss BattlesIt's not a slug-fest unless you want it to be. There are so many ways to kill the bosses.CONS1. Piraxis PointsYour skill points in the game. Given very rarely and you have to allocate them properly. While the abilities are enjoyable, perhaps I felt that the rate of skill point gain was a bit slow?2. Take-downsSo flashy and so loud. It's a wonder why no one can hear a take-down. Most of all, the target gets to have a look at your face.3. RollingIf you hug the wall and try to stealth roll to the next wall, you will see a "kung fu" barrel roll that makes absolutely no sense.4. KO'ed BodiesThey are there like forever. A tranquilizer dart keeps them on the ground permanently. You can leave and return and the bodies will still be there. Also, the rag doll dragging looks funny and weird, like a bug suddenly occurred.5. Guard RoutesStandard repeats. I don't know how to explain it, but knowing that a guard moves back and forth in a straight line, kind of makes it boring. It doesn't make the guard feel alive. 6. TriggersSome guard routes are only triggered when you enter within range of some guards. This makes alternative routes less viable because they don't move.7. BoxesYour inventory keeps ammunition in a 2 space box. 1 additional bullet requires a 2 space box? Inventory Tetris is not a fun mini-game.8. Bugsa. The female boss after Eliza Chan got bugged after I used both the Typhon and PEPS to kill her. She became permanently invisible and unable to move. I just shot her to death.b. Batter rechargers only 1 level of energy cellc. Dual takedown does not work on sitting opponents.9. Cut-scenesOnce is enough, no need to keep giving cut-scenes for every take-down,kill, Icarus landing or Typhoon firing.10. KeysGrenades and Holster weapon are next to each other on the keyboard (G & H). Imagine if you want to holster and you throw a grenade instead.Cloak and Typhoon are next to each. Imagine if you want to cloak and a Typhoon explosion happened instead.SUGGESTION1. Floor Cleaners Robots / Roombas?I noticed that the game had a lot of Floor Cleaner Robots that don't move around. Make them something that are moving around in the game. Then you hack them and use their cameras to spy on rooms.2. Vending MachinesI have to eat energy bars to replace my electric batteries that powers my robotic arm. While I suspect that it is most illogical, perhaps the vending machines could dispense energy drinks/food?3. Energy / HealthPerhaps, charging through a power point might be better than a energy bar? The power to move a prosthetic limb that can bash through walls comes from an energy bar? Painkillers gets you more health? Perhaps energy shields?4. Hack CommunicationsHack their radio signal and you can jam them, isolate one group, give them false orders, reduce alert status or anything else you can think of. Group link them, so they check on those missing.5. DisguisesSpeaks for itself. Add illusions too?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2, 2015
												Deus Ex is a game where you uncover a deep and mysterious, yet believable story behind a growing world of biotechnology.You play the role of a security specialist named Adam Jensen who works in a firm that develops augmentations to restore or enhance human capabilities. Jensen sees his life turn around for the worst when his company suffers from a terrorrist attack, leaving him in a coma for 6 months and forcing him to use that same biotechnology to prevent him from dying and take his revenge against the criminals.The best thing in Deus Ex is that your choices matter, the way the objectives are approached is rewarded differently as you complete both the main story and the side-missions. Use brute force or stealth, it's all up to you.27 hours of pure entertainment and gaming quality with plenty of replay value to easily double that amount.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2015
												What can be said about this game that has not already been said?Beautifully made, a powerful and very thought provoking message, and one of the most customizable stealth games I have ever experienced. Directors cut betters on the already great game by adding better boss fights among other things, but never once was I un-immersed or didn't care. Every enemy I shot I cringed because everyone had so much character I felt it was a shame to take that life. A SHAME. These are video game characters were talking about here! Pixels and polygons on a screen! Any game that can make me feel pity, remorse, and regret for killing someone is a great game, especially when those people are the "bad guys" (see these air quotes I'm making with my computer?) and don't serve any purpose to story! This doesn't even begin to state how good of a game this is, but I will continue lest this become a gushing session!That being said I do have a few gripes about the game. (Few and far between)From what I heard, directors cut runs on an earlier engine, which makes sense. I experienced well over 10 or 15 crashes while playing the game, most often in city areas. If you get this game SAVE OFTEN! As for how it runs its fine for me (I have a pretty low end PC so low end PC's shouldn't have too much trouble) and I can't speak for higher end PC's. The best part about this game, despite the crashes bugs etc., is the story.So though provoking, every second you are forced to think about the outcome and how things might turn out. Your own morals, what do you believe in? What kind of future do you want? What will doing this achieve? Every second you doubt and trust the people who appear to be allies and the people you think are the enemy. Every line delivered during the story has so much more meaning then what the flesh shows. It's just a story and a game not worth missing. For full price, maybe, maybe not. On a sale? 3 copies please!But say you’re not in it for the story, you’re just looking for a stealth / cover shooter fix. Well, this game offers the solution! The game mechanics are spot on and really do the game justice. The stealth mechanics are deep and engaging, and the combat mechanics are great as well, enemies are smart and flank you, and you can do much without flaking the enemy. Hacking provides a great little mini game that opens up many of the maps hidden secrets. Did I say this game is loaded with Easter eggs and secrets? Well, it is! Despite me trying to avoid gushing, I gushed. I apologize. So I’ll just end with this, I can't remember the exact line, but here is one of my favorites."Judge, jury and executioner, eh Jenson?”

Every second you doubt and trust the people who appear to be allies and the people you think are the enemy. Every line delivered during the story has so much more meaning then what the flesh shows. It's just a story and a game not worth missing. For full price, maybe, maybe not. On a sale? 3 copies please!But say you’re not in it for the story, you’re just looking for a stealth / cover shooter fix. Well, this game offers the solution! The game mechanics are spot on and really do the game justice. The stealth mechanics are deep and engaging, and the combat mechanics are great as well, enemies are smart and flank you, and you can do much without flaking the enemy. Hacking provides a great little mini game that opens up many of the maps hidden secrets. Did I say this game is loaded with Easter eggs and secrets? Well, it is! Despite me trying to avoid gushing, I gushed. I apologize. So I’ll just end with this, I can't remember the exact line, but here is one of my favorites."Judge, jury and executioner, eh Jenson?”

												This game is my favorite so far in the franchise.  One thing that makes this game so great is that you can choose how to take out enemies.  If you want to complete a mission using only stealth, go right ahead.  If you want to run in guns blazing, you can do that too.  If you want to mix it up, feel free.
